(2) Provide appropriate catchlines, headings and titles for sections and other subdivisions of the Code printed in the supplement, and make changes in such catchlines, headings and titles. (3) Assign appropriate numbers to sections and other subdivisions to be inserted in the Code and, where necessary to accommodate new material, change existing sections or other subdivision numbers. (4) Change the words "this ordinance," "this resolution" or words of the same meaning to "this chapter," "this article," "this division," etc., as the case may be or to "sections ____________ to ____________ " (inserting section numbers to indicate the sections of the Code which embody the substantive sections of the ordinances and resolutions incorporated into the Code). (5) Make other nonsubstantive changes necessary to preserve the original meaning of the ordinance or resolution sections inserted into the Code; but in no case shall the codifier make any change in the meaning or effect of material included in the supplement or already embodied in the Code. (Code 1987, § 1-7) Sec. 1-8. - General penalty. (a) In this section, the phrase "violation of this Code" or "violation of any such provision of this Code or any such ordinance" means any of the following: (1) Doing an act that is prohibited or made or declared unlawful, an offense, a violation or a misdemeanor by ordinance, by statute adopted by reference in this Code, by state rule or regulation adopted by reference in this Code, or by rule or regulation authorized by ordinance. (2) Failure to perform an act that is required to be performed by ordinance, by statute adopted by reference in this Code, by state rule or regulation adopted by reference in this Code or by rule or regulation authorized by ordinance. (3) Failure to perform an act if the failure is prohibited or is made or declared unlawful, an offense, a violation or a misdemeanor by ordinance, by statute adopted by reference in this Code, by state rule or regulation adopted by reference in this Code or by rule or regulation authorized by ordinance. (b) In this section, the phrase "violation of this Code" or "violation of any such provision of this Code or any such ordinance" does not include the failure of a county officer or county employee to perform an official duty unless it is specifically provided that the failure to perform the duty is to be punished as provided in this section. (c) Unless a higher penalty is otherwise specified, whenever in this Code or in any ordinance of the county any act is prohibited or is made or declared to be unlawful or an offense, or whenever in this Code or any ordinance the doing of any act is required and the failure to do such act is declared to be unlawful, and no specific penalty is provided, and unless otherwise provided by state law, the violation of any such provision of this Code or any such ordinance shall be punished by a fine not to exceed $1,000.00 and imprisonment in the county jail not exceeding 60 days, or both a fine and sentence of imprisonment; and all sentences may be in the alternative and fines may be imposed with the alternative of sentence to imprisonment and labor if the fines are not paid. (d) Violations of this Code may be abated by injunctive or other equitable relief. The imposition of a penalty does not prevent injunctive relief. (e) The infliction of a penalty under the provisions of this section shall not prevent the revocation of any permit or license or the taking of other punitive or remedial action where called for or permitted under the provisions of the county's Special and Local Acts or Code. (f) Each day any violation of this Code shall continue shall constitute a separate offense. (Code 1987, § 1-8) State Law reference— Limitations on penalties, O.C.G.A. § 36-1-20(b); imposition of additional penalty for certain drug offenses, O.C.G.A. § 15-21-100; imposition of additional penalty for offense of driving under the influence of alcohol or drugs, O.C.G.A. § 15-21-112; additional penalty to be imposed in criminal and traffic cases to provide training to law enforcement officers and prosecuting officials, O.C.G.A. § 15-21-73; additional penalty assessments for jail construction and staffing, O.C.G.A. § 15-21-91; punishment for misdemeanors generally, O.C.G.A. § 17-10-3; deposit of driver's license for violations of laws pertaining to traffic and motor vehicles, O.C.G.A. § 17-6-11; payments to peace officers annuity and benefit fund from revenues collected from fines and fees, O.C.G.A. § 47-17-60 et seq.; alternative punishments for violations involving a traffic offense, O.C.G.A. § 17-10-3(e). Sec. 1-9. - Effect of repeal of ordinances and resolutions. (a) The repeal of an ordinance or resolution shall not revive any ordinance or resolution in force before or at the time the ordinance or resolution repeal took effect. (b) The repeal of an ordinance or resolution shall not affect any punishment or penalty incurred before the repeal took effect, nor any suit, prosecution or proceeding pending at the time of the repeal, for an offense committed or cause of action arising under the ordinance or resolution repealed, nor any right acquired or liability incurred under any ordinance or resolution repealed. (Code 1987, § 1-9) Sec. 1-10. - Provisions not affected by Code. Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall be construed to repeal or otherwise affect the validity of any of the following: (1) Any act committed or done or any penalty or forfeiture incurred or any contract or right established or accruing before the effective date of this Code. (2) Any ordinance, resolution, motion or order promising or guaranteeing the payment of money for the county or authorizing the issuance of any bonds of the county or any evidence of the county's indebtedness. (3) Any contract or obligation assumed by the county. (4) Any right or franchise granted by the county. (5) Any ordinance, resolution, motion or order relating to specific public improvements or assessments therefor. (6) Any ordinance, resolution, motion or order providing for the levy or collection of taxes or for an annual budget or appropriations. (7) Any ordinance, resolution, motion or order pertaining to zoning. (8) Any ordinance, resolution, motion or order relating to the investment of county funds. (9) Any ordinance, resolution, motion, order, rule or regulation prescribing regulations, compensation, positions, classification, and other matters pertaining to county officers or employees, not inconsistent herewith. (10) Any ordinance, resolution, motion or order dedicating or accepting any plat or subdivision in the county. (11) Any ordinance, resolution, motion or order naming, renaming, opening, closing, prescribing grades, etc., of streets, roads, bridges and other public ways. (12) Any ordinance, resolution, motion or order establishing utility connection charges, deposits, service charges or other charges not inconsistent with this Code. (13) Any ordinance, resolution, motion or order creating, establishing, prescribing or abolishing housing authorities, urban renewal projects and minimum housing standards. (14) Any ordinance, resolution, motion or order not inconsistent with this Code prescribing or providing traffic regulations at specific places, such as speed limits, through streets, stop intersections, yield intersections, one-way travel, no left turns, no right turns, traffic-control by electrical devices, truck routes, loading zones, no parking zones and limited parking zones; this enumeration is not to be by way of exclusion. (15) Any ordinance, resolution, motion or order pertaining to or providing for zoning or subdivision regulations, or airport hazard districts; or accepting any plat. (16) Any resolution or ordinance which, by its own terms, is effective for a stated or limited term. (17) Any resolution or ordinance describing or altering the boundaries of the county. (18) The administrative resolutions or ordinances of the county not in conflict or inconsistent with the provisions of this Code. (19) Any resolution or ordinance levying or imposing taxes not included in this Code. (20) Any ordinance or resolution of agreement with another political subdivision. (Code 1987, § 1-10) Sec. 1-11. - Severability. The sections, paragraphs, sentences, clauses and phrases of this Code, and of codes or other provisions adopted by reference herein, are severable, and if any such phrase, clause, sentence, paragraph or section shall be declared invalid by the valid judgement or decree of any court of competent jurisdiction, such invalidity shall not affect any of the remaining phrases, clauses, sentences, paragraphs and sections of this Code and provisions adopted by reference, since the same would have been enacted by the board of commissioners without the incorporation therein of any such invalid phrase, clause, sentence, paragraph or section. (Code 1987, § 1-11) Sec. 1-12. - Provisions considered as continuations of existing ordinances. The provisions appearing in this Code, insofar as they are the same as those of ordinances and resolutions existing at the time of adoption of this Code, shall be considered as continuations thereof and not as new enactments. Sec. 1-13. - Prior offenses, penalties, contracts or rights not affected by adoption of Code. (a) Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall affect any offense or act committed or done or any penalty or forfeiture incurred or any contract or right established or accruing before the effective date of this Code. (b) The adoption of this Code shall not be interpreted as authorizing or permitting any use or the continuance of any use of a structure or premises in violation of any ordinance or resolution in effect on the date of adoption of this Code. Sec. 1-14. - Altering Code, ordinance or other public document. (a) It shall be unlawful for any person in the county to change or amend by additions or deletions, any part of this Code, or to insert or delete pages or portions hereof, or to alter or tamper with such Code in any manner whatsoever which will cause the law of the county to be misrepresented thereby. (b) It shall be unlawful for any person to deface, mutilate, or in any other manner alter any other document or record of the municipal government. Sec. 1-15. - Prior offenses, penalties, contracts or rights not affected by adoption of Code. (a) Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall affect any offense or act committed or done or any penalty or forfeiture incurred or any contract or right established or accruing before the effective date of this Code. (b) The adoption of this Code shall not be interpreted as authorizing or permitting any use or the continuance of any use of a structure or premises in violation of any ordinance or resolution in effect on the date of adoption of this Code. Sec. 1-16. - Rates, charges, and fees established. (a) Unless otherwise provided for, all rates, charges, or fees necessary for the administration and enforcement of the provisions of this Code shall be as currently established or as hereafter adopted by motion, resolution or ordinance of the board of county commissioners, from time to time. Any rates, charges, or fees established by the county pursuant to the regulations or requirements established herein may be changed from time to time by the board of county commissioners, and such changes shall be considered an amendment to this Code. (b) Whenever any provision of this Code provides that a rate, charge, or fee shall be established by the board of county commissioners, from time to time, and the amount of such rate, charge, or fee is not expressed in this Code in any dollar amount, then the amount of such rate, charge, or fee shall be the most recent and latest amount established, set or fixed by the board of county commissioners by ordinance, resolution or motion.

div.head: Chapter 2 - ADMINISTRATION[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Home rule for counties, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, ¶ I; supplemental powers of municipalities and counties, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, ¶ III; claims against counties, O.C.G.A. § 36-11-1 et seq.; provisions applicable to counties and municipalities, O.C.G.A. § 36-60-1 et seq.; provisions applicable to counties and municipalities, O.C.G.A. § 36-80-2 et seq.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 2-1. - Records management. The board of commissioners' office shall be responsible for records management activities. The clerk or assistant clerk shall designate an officer to act for and on behalf of the county board of commissioners coordinating all records management matters. Records shall be maintained in accordance with approved retention schedules. (Code 1987, § 2-1; Res. of 1-3-1984) State Law reference— Georgia Records Act, O.C.G.A. § 50-18-90 et seq. Secs. 2-2—2-22. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - BOARDS, COMMITTEES AND COMMISSIONS DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Secs. 2-23—2-47. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - ETHICS BOARD[2]
Footnotes: --- (2) --- State Law reference— Codes of ethics and conflicts of interest, O.C.G.A. § 45-10-1 et seq.
Sec. 2-48. - Purposes of division. This division is adopted to: (1) State principles of ethics which are to be applied in public service; (2) Identify minimum standards of ethical conduct for public servants; (3) Require that public servants engage in ethical practices which always meet minimum standards; (4) Encourage public servants to pursue the highest ethical ideals which they can achieve; (5) Promote public confidence in the integrity of public servants; (6) Encourage members of the public to seek public office or employment, to serve on public boards, to assist public servants as volunteers, and to take pride in participating in the governmental process; (7) Establish penalties, as appropriate, for public servants who violate the public trust; and (8) Provide for a just and reasonable balance among the rights of all individuals who are directly affected by the operation of this division. (Code 1987, § 2-23; Ord. of 4-1-2003, § 2-3) Sec. 2-49. - Policy statement. Any person in the employ of the county board of commissioners should: (1) Put loyalty to the highest moral principles and to the county above loyalty to persons, party, or government department; (2) Uphold the Constitutional laws, and legal regulations of the United States and the State of Georgia and of Liberty County therein and never be a party to their evasion; (3) Give a full day's labor for a full day's pay and give to the performance of his duties his earnest effort and best thought; (4) Seek to find and employ more efficient and economical ways of getting tasks accomplished; (5) Never discriminate unfairly by the dispensing of special favors or privileges to anyone, whether for remuneration or not, and never accept, for himself or his family, favors or benefits under circumstances which might be construed by reasonable persons as influencing the performance of his governmental duties; (6) Make no private promises of any kind binding upon the duties of office, since a government employee has no private word which can be binding on public duty; (7) Engage in no business with the government, either directly or indirectly, which is inconsistent with the conscientious performance of his governmental duties; (8) Never use any information coming to him confidentially in the performance of government duties as a means for making private profit; (9) Expose corruption wherever discovered; (10) Uphold these principles, ever conscious that public office is a public trust. (Code 1987, § 2-23.1; Ord. No. 2005-001, 2-1-2005) Sec. 2-50. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Board means the board of commissioners of Liberty County, Georgia; used generically, the term "board" may mean any voting body. Confidential information means information which has been obtained in the course of holding public office, employment, an independent contract or otherwise acting as a public servant, and which information is not available to members of the public under the Georgia Open Records Act or other law or regulation and which the public servant is not authorized to disclose. Conflict of interest means any interest, transaction, or other conduct which is prohibited by this division. Employee means a person, other than an elected or appointed public servant, employed and paid a salary to work for the county, whether full-time, part-time, or otherwise subject to the county's personnel policy, and including those officially selected but not yet serving; but does not include an independent contractor. Ethics board means the board of ethics established under the provisions of this division. Gift means any benefit or thing or act of value which is conveyed to or performed for the benefit of the recipient, including any advance, award, contract, contribution, deposit, employment, favor, forbearance, gift, gratuity, honorarium, loan, payment, service, subscription, or the promise that any of these things or acts of value will be conferred in the future, if such thing or act of value is conferred or performed without the lawful exchange of consideration which is at least equal in value to the thing or act conferred or performed. Immediate family means: (1) A public servant's spouse; (2) A public servant's relative by marriage, lineal descent or adoption who receives, directly or indirectly, more than one-half of his support from the public servant or from whom the public servant receives, directly or indirectly, more than one-half of his support; (3) A public servant's parents, parents-in-law, sisters, sisters-in-law, brothers, brothers-in-law, stepparents, stepbrothers or stepsisters; and (4) An individual claimed by the public servant or the public servant's spouse as a dependent under the United States Internal Revenue Code. Office or public office means any of the following: (1) An elective position on the board; (2) An appointive county position in which a public servant serves for a specified term, except a position on a body which is independent of the board and not subject to its direct control, to include, by way of illustration only, positions on the Liberty County Industrial Authority, the Liberty County Hospital Authority, and other similar bodies; or (3) An appointive county position which is filled by the board or its designee and in which the incumbent serves at the pleasure of the appointing authority, to include, without limitation, the county engineer, the county and the county attorney. Officer means any person elected or appointed to hold an office, as defined in this section. Official action means any act, action, approval, decision, denial, directive, disapproval, inaction, order, performance, nonperformance, recommendation, vote, or other direct result of a public servant's exercise of discretionary authority in connection with the public servant's public position. Partner in interest means, when used in this division in connection with a public servant, as in the phrase "a public servant or a partner in interest" any and all of the following: (1) A member of the public servant's immediate family; (2) A business with which the public servant or a member of the public servant's immediate family is an owner, partner, director, officer, employee or independent contractor in relation to the business; provided, however, that a business shall not be deemed a partner in interest under this division if the interest of the public servant or his immediate family member is de minimis; (3) Any other person with whom the public servant or a member of his immediate family is negotiating or has an agreement concerning future employment or the future conferring of any pecuniary benefit, whether in the public servant's own name or the name of any business or person from whom the public servant is entitled, or expects to become entitled, to receive any pecuniary benefit, as a result of a contract or transaction which is, or which is expected to become, the subject of an official action by or with the county. The term "partner in interest" does not imply or require any form of legal partnership or formal agreement; and (4) When used in the phrase "a public servant or a partner in interest," the term "partner in interest" refers only to a partner in interest of the public servant to whom reference is being made, and not to any other person's partner in interest. Public servant means any officer or employee of the county, as such terms are defined in this section. (Code 1987, § 2-24; Ord. of 4-1-2003, § 2-4) Sec. 2-51. - Exemptions. (a) This division does not prevent any public servant from accepting other employment or following any pursuit which in no way interferes with the full and faithful discharge of his public duties, provided that the public servant complies with all applicable county and state requirements, including any requirements imposed by this division. (b) No public servant shall be deemed to have a conflict of interest by virtue of sharing, directly or indirectly, in the benefit of a lawful county action when the benefit to the public servant is substantially the same as the benefit to the public at large or to a segment of the public to whom the benefit is provided in a nondiscriminatory manner. (c) This division does not prohibit public servants from taking any official action properly within the scope of their duties with respect to any proposal to enact or modify law or public policy. (d) This division does not prohibit an elected official from raising campaign contributions in any manner which is otherwise permitted by law. (e) Actions which might otherwise be alleged to constitute a conflict of interest shall be deemed to comply with this division and not to be a conflict of interest if: (1) Before acting, the public servant requested and received an opinion from the county attorney or the office of the state attorney general; and (2) The actions taken were consistent with the opinion. (Code 1987, § 2-25; Ord. of 4-1-2003, § 2-5) Sec. 2-52. - Conflict of interests and confidential information. (a) Except as otherwise permitted under applicable state and county laws and regulations, no public servant shall: (1) Take any official action with regard to any matter where the public servant might have a direct or indirect pecuniary interest, or where the public servant has a fiduciary duty or responsibility to another entity in the same matter; (2) Intentionally use or disclose confidential information in any way that could result in the receipt of any pecuniary benefit for the public servant, for the partner in interest of the public servant, or for any other persons; or (3) Act in a manner contrary to the provisions of art. 1, § 2, ¶ I of the Constitution of the State of Georgia, as well as any and all other laws of this state applicable to the performance of public office. (b) Notwithstanding the mandatory provisions of this division, all public servants are further encouraged to avoid the appearance of impropriety or misdealing so as to better preserve and ensure the public's confidence and trust in local government. (Code 1987, § 2-26; Ord. of 4-1-2003, § 2-6) Sec. 2-53. - Acceptance of gifts prohibited. (a) No public servant shall accept or receive, directly or indirectly, from any person, including one whose identity is unknown to the public servant, any gift or other item of value under circumstances in which it can reasonably be inferred that the gift is intended to influence the public servant in the performance or nonperformance of any official duty or as a reward for any official action of the public servant. (b) No public servant shall solicit from any person, directly or indirectly, any personal benefit, regardless of value, or the promise of receiving a personal benefit in the future, for the public servant in connection with his office. (Code 1987, § 2-27; Ord. of 4-1-2003, § 2-7) Sec. 2-54. - Other abuses or misuses of position. (a) No public servant shall hold any other office, elected or appointed, in any other governmental entity, when the duties of such office are incompatible with the proper discharge of the public servant's duties with the county. (b) No public servant shall use or attempt to use his office improperly to request, grant, or obtain in any manner any unlawful privileges, advantages or financial benefits for himself or others; provided that nothing in this provision shall be construed to prohibit or discourage any public servant from performing any official duty or action zealously and enthusiastically. (c) All public servants have a fiduciary duty to use county fiscal and human resources in a manner which advances the public interest, and to refrain from using county property and resources for their personal benefit; therefore, public servants are prohibited from using county property and resources for personal benefit or in any manner which violates any applicable law or policy or which is not otherwise authorized. Furthermore, a public servant shall not direct employees of the county or other public servants to misappropriate or use county property and resources for any purpose other than authorized by law. (Code 1987, § 2-28; Ord. of 4-1-2003, § 2-8) Sec. 2-55. - Public contracts. (a) The county is prohibited from entering into any contract with a public servant or the public servant's partner in interest to the extent prohibited by this Code or the laws of the state. (b) Any contract entered into in violation of this section may be voided by the county in an action commenced within three years of the date on which the board, or the department or officer acting for the county in regard to the allocation of funds from which such payment is derived, knew or should have known that a violation of this section occurred. This section does not affect the application of any state statute. (Code 1987, § 2-29; Ord. of 4-1-2003, § 2-9) Sec. 2-56. - Deliberation and vote prohibited. Except as otherwise provided by law, no public servant shall, in such capacity, participate in the discussion, debate, deliberation or vote, or otherwise take part in the decision-making process on any agenda item before the board or other body in which the public servant has a conflict of interest or other impermissible relationship as provided in this division. (Code 1987, § 2-30; Ord. of 4-1-2003, § 2-10) Sec. 2-57. - Duty to leave meeting. (a) To avoid the appearance of impropriety, after any public servant is determined to have a conflict of interest or a potential conflict of interest in any matter, and once all questions relating to the conflict of interest have been answered to the satisfaction of the board or other relevant decision maker, the public servant shall immediately leave the meeting room, except that if the matter is being considered at a public meeting, the public servant may remain in the area of the room occupied by the general public. If a public servant who has a conflict of interest in a matter is present as a member of the board or other body which is to consider the matter, the public servant shall leave his regular seat as a member of the body, and not return to it until deliberation and action on the matter is completed. (b) Nothing herein shall require members of voting bodies to leave their seats while action is taken regarding any item contained on a "consent agenda" on which there is no deliberation, the public servant's conflict has been disclosed, and the public servant abstains from voting on the item. (Code 1987, § 2-31; Ord. of 4-1-2003, § 2-11) Sec. 2-58. - Disclosure of conflict of interest or potential conflict of interest. (a) A public servant who has or may have, a conflict of interest in a matter which requires an official action by the board or other body, shall, before the matter is decided, disclose the conflict of interest or the potential or alleged conflict of interest. All questions relating to a conflict of interest shall be resolved before the matter is decided, and if the matter comes before the board or other body, before the board or other body engages in any consideration of the merits of the matter. (b) The county attorney shall at all times comply with the state laws and standards governing the professional conduct of lawyers (collectively, the "bar standards"). If the county attorney has or may have a conflict of interest in any matter before the board to the extent requiring disclosure to the board under the bar standards (such as that arising from the representation of a party whose legal position is adverse to that of the board), the county attorney shall disclose the same to the board. If the county attorney and the board determine that the county attorney's office cannot resolve the conflict in a manner which will allow the county attorney's office to perform its duties properly in the matter, then the county attorney shall be disqualified from acting in such matter. Notwithstanding any provisions herein to the contrary, the conduct of the county attorney in such matters shall in no event be amenable to review by the ethics board, but shall instead be subject to review and discipline by the State Bar of Georgia as provided in the bar standards. (Code 1987, § 2-32; Ord. of 4-1-2003, § 2-12) Sec. 2-59. - Board of ethics. (a) There is created a board of ethics, which shall be deemed an instrumentality of the county, to review and, if necessary, hear complaints filed against any public officer subject to the provisions of this division, if such complaints involve impropriety of said public officers and violations of the provisions of this division, and if such violation affects the elected official's ability to carry out his official duties. (b) The ethics board shall consist of three members who are residents of the county and shall serve without compensation; the membership to be reflective of the citizenry of the county. Members of the board of ethics shall not be elected officials or county employees. (c) Ethics board members shall be appointed by the board for terms of two years, and shall hold office until their successor is appointed and duly qualified, as follows: The chairperson of the board shall appoint one member, the remaining members of the board shall appoint one member, and the full board shall together appoint one member. Ethics board members may serve consecutive terms. (d) The ethics board shall elect its own chairperson from its membership. (e) The ethics board's deliberations and actions upon complaints shall be in meetings, conducted in accordance with the Georgia Open Meetings Act. (f) The board shall provide such staff support for the ethics board as the board determines to be necessary for the ethics board to fulfill its duties. The county attorney is designated to be the legal advisor for the ethics board. The county attorney shall not be eligible for appointment to the ethics board. (g) Prior to the appointment of any member to the ethics board, public notice of the opportunity for service on the ethics board shall be made in accordance with the board's then-current practice with respect to the advertisement of board appointments generally. (h) The board may remove any member of the ethics board for good cause. As used herein, the term "good cause" shall mean: (1) The failure to regularly attend meetings of the ethics board in accordance with policies established from time to time by the board; (2) Misconduct or misfeasance in office; (3) An event of disability rendering the member incapable of fully and properly discharging his duties; or (4) Any conduct or activity inconsistent with his service on the ethics board or which otherwise undermines its effectiveness, all as determined by the board in its sole and absolute discretion. Prior to the removal of any member of the ethics board, the board shall give the member written notice of the removal and the reasons therefor. Following receipt of such notice, the member being removed shall be afforded an opportunity to formally reply to the contents of such notice in a form and manner to be specified by the board, to include, without limitation, a public hearing regarding such matter. In any event, the decisions of the board regarding such removal shall be final and absolute. (Code 1987, § 2-33; Ord. of 4-1-2003, § 2-13; Ord. No. 2007-001, § I, 3-6-2007) Sec. 2-60. - Duties and powers of the board. (a) The board shall, in addition to its other duties: (1) Adopt written rules governing its procedures and providing for the holding of meetings, which rules shall be subject to the approval of the board; a copy of the rules shall be filed with the county; (2) Conduct hearings as needed to hear and decide specific cases in which a violation of this division is alleged in a complaint brought under this division; (3) Prescribe and make available forms for use under this division, as approved by the county attorney; and (4) When it deems it appropriate, request the county attorney for assistance in compelling the production of documents and witnesses to assist the ethics board in the conduct of any investigation. All opinions and other public documents of the ethics board shall be filed with the county and are open to public inspection in accordance with the Georgia Open Records Act. (b) The ethics board shall not have the power to issue advisory opinions, but its primary purpose under this division shall be to review complaints filed hereunder. It shall be the responsibility of the county attorney to render an opinion with respect to the prospective conduct of all public servants. An opinion need not be written, and may be provided directly to the requestor of such opinion. Neither a request for an opinion, nor the making of a statement concerning a potential conflict of interest made by a public servant in the course of abstaining from voting or making a motion of self-recusal, shall create a presumption or inference that a public servant actually has a personal interest in the matter about which the opinion was requested. Additionally, the ethics board shall have no power or authority to impose any penalty or sanction any public servant pursuant to this division, but such power shall be exercised exclusively by the board. (Code 1987, § 2-34; Ord. of 4-1-2003, § 2-14) Sec. 2-61. - Limitations on board's power. The ethics board does not have the authority to reverse or otherwise modify a prior action of the board or any other public servant, or public body, but its powers shall be strictly limited as set forth in this division. (Code 1987, § 2-35; Ord. of 4-1-2003, § 2-15) Sec. 2-62. - Procedures for hearing complaints. (a) Any resident of the county may file a written complaint, signed and sworn, with the county alleging a violation of this division. (b) A complaint shall specify the provisions of this division alleged to have been violated and facts alleged to constitute the violation. (c) Upon receipt of such a complaint, but in any event not later than three working days after receipt, the county shall acknowledge receipt to the complainant, and forward the complaint simultaneously to the ethics board, the person who is complained against and the county attorney. (d) During any investigation and during any hearing which is conducted to determine whether a violation of this division has occurred: (1) The person under investigation or the accused may, at such person's expense, be represented by counsel of his choosing; and (2) The accused or his representative, if any, shall have an opportunity to: a. Challenge the sufficiency of any complaint which has been filed against him; b. Examine all documents and records obtained or prepared by the ethics board in connection with the matter heard; c. Bring witnesses; d. Establish all pertinent facts and circumstances; e. Question or refute testimony or evidence, including the opportunity to confront and cross-examine adverse witnesses; and f. Exercise, to the extent the ethics board, in its discretion, determines to be just and reasonable, any pretrial discovery procedure usually available in civil actions (to the extent authorized by law). (e) The following principles shall apply to evidence in connection with hearings conducted by the board: (1) The ethics board shall not be bound to adhere to statutory rules of evidence, but shall be fundamentally fair in its administration of evidence; (2) During any hearing conducted by the ethics board to determine whether a violation of this division has occurred, all evidence including certified copies of records which the ethics board considers shall be fully offered and made a part of the record in the proceedings; (3) The accused or any other person under investigation shall be afforded adequate opportunity to rebut or offer countervailing evidence; (4) The ethics board shall inform the accused or his counsel of exculpatory evidence in its possession; and (5) The standard of evidence in hearings conducted under this division shall be clear and convincing evidence admitted at the hearing. (f) The ethics board, in addition to its other duties and powers, may: (1) With the consent of the board or its designee, appoint a hearing officer to conduct hearings under this division; (2) Order testimony to be taken by deposition before any individual who is designated by the ethics board and, in such instances, to compel testimony and the production of evidence to the extent it is otherwise lawfully authorized to do so; and (3) Require any person to submit in writing such reports and answers to questions relevant to the proceedings conducted under this division as the board may prescribe, such submission to be made within such period and under oath or otherwise as the board may determine. (g) The person complained against shall have 30 days from the day after the county received the complaint to submit a written response to the complaint prior to the ethics board deciding whether to hold a hearing. (h) Within 60 days following the filing of the complaint, the ethics board shall review and consider the same, and, if a hearing is to be held, shall set a date certain for the hearing to take place within 30 days, unless the accused petitions for and the ethics board consents to a later date. (i) As soon as practicable after giving due consideration to a complaint, or, if a hearing was held, after the hearing, the ethics board shall take any action or combination of actions which it deems appropriate and which it is lawfully empowered to take, including, but not limited to, the following: (1) Dismiss the complaint based on any of the following grounds: a. The complaint does not allege facts sufficient to constitute a violation of this division; b. The ethics board has no jurisdiction over the matter; c. Failure of the complainant to cooperate in the ethics board's review and consideration of the complaint; d. The complaint is defective in a manner which results in the ethics board being unable to make any sound determination; or e. The complaint is otherwise frivolous; (2) Determine that no violation of this division has occurred; (3) Determine that the complaint alleges facts sufficient to constitute a violation of this division and that the ethics board will conduct a hearing, in which case the ethics board shall promptly send written notice of such determination to the accused and to the party who made the complaint; (4) Determine that further information must be obtained in order for the ethics board to determine whether the complaint alleges facts sufficient to constitute a violation of this division; a. Conduct its own investigation with respect to any alleged violation; b. Request the county attorney to investigate the complaint and report all findings back to the ethics board; c. Schedule the complaint for further review and consideration at a future time certain, in which case the ethics board shall promptly send written notice of such determination to the accused and to the party who made the complaint; or d. Refer the complaint to any appropriate authorities for criminal investigation or prosecution; (5) Refer the complaint, along with the ethics board's findings and conclusions, to the board for disciplinary action or other suitable remedial action following any hearing required under this division; or (6) In the case of alleged violations of this division involving employees of the county, refer the matter to the county administrator for review and possible disciplinary action pursuant to the county personnel policy; it being understood that the ethics board shall have no jurisdiction over matters relating to county employees, but that such matters shall be addressed solely by the county as set forth in its personnel policy. (j) After it has made its final determination, the board shall issue its written findings of fact and conclusions, and may issue any additional reports, opinions and recommendations as it deems advisable under the circumstances. All such reports shall be in compliance with all state and county laws, including, without limitation, the Georgia Open Records Act. All such reports shall be reviewed by the county attorney prior to their issuance. (Code 1987, § 2-36; Ord. of 4-1-2003, § 2-16) Sec. 2-63. - Ex parte communications. After a complaint has been filed and during the pendency of a complaint before the ethics board, no member of the ethics board may communicate directly or indirectly with any party or other person about any issue of fact or law regarding the complaint, except that: (1) The members of the board may obtain legal advice from the county attorney and may discuss the complaint with other authorized persons; and (2) The members of the ethics board may discuss the complaint at a lawfully conducted meeting or otherwise in the performance of their duties. (Code 1987, § 2-37; Ord. of 4-1-2003, § 2-17) Sec. 2-64. - Statute of limitations. No action may be taken on any complaint which is filed later than one year after a violation of this division is alleged to have occurred, and a complaint alleging a violation must be filed within six months from the date the complainant knew or should have known of the action alleged to be a violation; provided that no action may be taken on any complaint alleging violations of this division prior to the effective date of this division. (Code 1987, § 2-38; Ord. of 4-1-2003, § 2-18) Sec. 2-65. - Penalties. Any public servant who knowingly violates any provision of this division as set forth above shall be subject to disciplinary action by the board which may include censure and either public or private reprimand; provided, however, that any violations of this division by an employee shall subject such employee to adverse disciplinary action as set forth in the county's personnel policy, including, but not limited to, suspension and termination. Additionally, until such time as the provisions of this division are formally made a part of and incorporated in the county's personnel policy, this division shall in no way bind employees of the county, but such employees shall adhere to the requirements and provisions of said personnel policy in lieu of this division. (Code 1987, § 2-39; Ord. of 4-1-2003, § 2-19) Sec. 2-66. - Reimbursement authorized. Upon the dismissal of any complaint filed hereunder or upon the ethics board's finding of no violation of this division, the public servant may request from the board that the reasonable costs and expenses actually incurred by said public servant in his defense of any such complaint be reimbursed. Upon receipt of such written request, the board, in its sole discretion, may elect to reimburse the public servant all or part of such expenses and costs, to include, but not be limited to, reasonable fees of individual counsel and all applicable costs reasonably incurred in connection with the proceedings authorized hereunder; provided, however, that such attorneys' fees shall be no more than the rate paid to the county attorney for similar representation. (Code 1987, § 2-40; Ord. of 4-1-2003, § 2-20) Sec. 2-67. - Appeal. Any final decision of the board pursuant to this division shall be reviewable by the superior court of the county; provided, however, that no action of the board refusing or failing to take action pursuant to this division shall be reviewable on appeal. Appeals to the superior court shall be filed within 30 days from the date of any final decision of the board. (Code 1987, § 2-41; Ord. of 4-1-2003, § 2-21) Sec. 2-68. - Penalties cumulative. The penalties prescribed in this division shall be cumulative and not exclusive of each other or of any other penalties which may be imposed pursuant to any other laws or policies. (Code 1987, § 2-42; Ord. of 4-1-2003, § 2-22) Secs. 2-69—2-98. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - PROCUREMENT POLICY
Sec. 2-99. - General provisions. (a) Generally. The county board of commissioners shall provide for a procurement system of quality and integrity; provide for the fair and equitable treatment of all persons or firms involved in purchasing by the county board of commissioners; ensure that supplies and services are procured efficiently, effectively, and at the most favorable prices available to the county board of commissioners; promote competition in contracting; and ensure that the county board of commissioner's purchasing actions are in full compliance with applicable federal standards, state, and local laws. (b) Applicability. This procurement policy applies to all procurement actions of the county board of commissioners as applicable for the expenditure of federal funds except as noted under "exclusions." However, nothing in this policy shall prevent the county board of commissioners from complying with the terms and conditions of any grant, contract, gift or bequest that is otherwise consistent with the law. When both federal and non-federal grant funds are used for a project, the work to be accomplished with the funds should be separately identified prior to procurement so that appropriate requirements can be applied, if necessary. If it is not possible to separate the funds, federal procurement regulations shall be applied to the total project. If funds and work can be separated and work can be completed by a new contract, then regulations applicable to the source of funding may be followed. (c) Definition. The term "procurement," as used in this policy, includes the procuring, purchasing, leasing, or renting of: (1) Goods, supplies, equipment, and materials; (2) Construction and maintenance; (3) Consultant services; (4) Architectural and engineering (AIE) services; and (5) Other services. (d) Changes in laws and regulations. In the event an applicable law or regulation is modified or eliminated, or a new law or regulation is adopted, the revised law or regulation shall, to the extent inconsistent with these policies, automatically supersede these policies. (e) Public access to procurement information. Most procurement information that is not proprietary is a matter of public record and shall be available to the public to the extent provided in the Georgia Freedom of Information Act. (Code 1987, § 2-101; Ord. No. 2010-007, § 3.1.0, 7-6-2010) Sec. 2-100. - Ethics in public contracting. (a) Generally. The county board of commissioners hereby establishes this code of conduct regarding procurement issues and actions and shall implement a system of sanctions for violations. This code of conduct, etc., is consistent with applicable federal, state, or local law. (b) Conflicts of interest. No employee, officer, board member, or agent of the county board of commissioners shall participate directly or indirectly in the selection or award of any contract if a conflict of interest, either real or apparent, would be involved. This type of conflict would be when one of the persons listed below has a direct financial interest, or employment or other contractual relationship, in a firm competing for the award: (1) An employee, officer, board member, or agent involved in making the award; (2) An organization which employs or is negotiating to employ, or has an arrangement concerning prospective employment of any of the above. (Code 1987, § 2-102; Ord. No. 2010-007, § 3.2.0, 7-6-2010) Sec. 2-101. - Purchasing procedures. (a) Micro purchase procedures. For any purchases not exceeding $5,000.00, the county board of commissioners will use the micro purchase procedure. Under micro purchase procedures, only one quote is required, provided the quote is considered reasonable. The county board of commissioners may award micro purchases without soliciting competitive quotations if the county administrator considers the price to be reasonable (e.g., based on recent research, experience, or purchases). The county board of commissioners shall make every effort to distribute micro purchases equitably among qualified vendors. (b) Small purchase procedures. For any amounts above the micro purchase ceiling, but not exceeding $25,000.00, the county board of commissioners may use small purchase procedures. Under small purchase procedures, the county board of commissioners shall obtain a minimum of three quotes. To the greatest extent feasible, and to promote competition, small purchases should be distributed among qualified sources. Quotes may be obtained orally (either in person or by phone), by fax, in writing, or through e-procurement. Award shall be made to the qualified vendor that provides the best value to the county board of commissioners. If award is to be made for reasons other than lowest price, documentation shall be provided in the contract file. The county board of commissioners shall not break down requirements aggregating more than the small purchase threshold (or the micro purchase threshold) into several purchases that are less than the applicable threshold merely to: (1) Permit use of the small purchase procedures; or (2) Avoid any requirements that apply to purchases that exceed the micro purchase threshold. (c) Sealed bids. Sealed bidding shall be used for all contracts that exceed the small purchase threshold and that are not competitive proposals or noncompetitive proposals, as these terms are defined in this document. Sealed bidding is the method for procuring construction, supply, and non-complex service contracts that are expected to exceed $25,000.00. (d) Competitive proposals. Unlike sealed bidding, the competitive proposal method permits: consideration of technical factors other than price; discussion with firms making proposals concerning offers submitted; negotiation of contract price or estimated cost and other contract terms and conditions; revision of proposals before the final contractor selection; and the withdrawal of an offer at any time up until the point of award. Award is normally made on the basis of the proposal that represents the best overall value, considering price and other factors, e.g., technical expertise, past experience, quality of proposed staffing, etc., set forth in the solicitation and not solely the lowest price. (e) Noncompetitive proposals. (1) Conditions for use. Procurement by noncompetitive proposals (sole-source) may be used only when the award of a contract is not feasible using small purchase procedures, sealed bids, cooperative purchasing, or competitive proposals, and if one of the following applies: a. The item is available only from a single source, based on a good faith review of available sources; b. An emergency exists that seriously threatens the public health, welfare, or safety, or endangers property, or would otherwise cause serious injury to the citizens of the county, as may arise by reason of a flood, earthquake, epidemic, riot, equipment failure, or similar event. In such cases, there must be an immediate and serious need for supplies, services, or construction such that the need cannot be met through any of the other procurement methods, and the emergency procurement shall be limited to those supplies, services, or construction necessary simply to meet the emergency; c. The federal or state grantee authorizes the use of noncompetitive proposals; or d. After solicitation of a number of sources, competition is determined inadequate. (2) Justification. Each procurement that is done based on noncompetitive proposals shall be supported by a written justification for the selection of this method. The justification shall be approved in writing by the county administrator and/or board of commissioners. Poor planning or lack of planning is not justification for emergency or sole-source procurements. The justification, to be included in the procurement file, shall be provided. (f) Cooperative purchasing intergovernmental agreements. The county board of commissioners may enter into state and/or local cooperative or intergovernmental agreements to purchase or use common supplies, equipment, or services. The decision to use an interagency agreement instead of conducting a direct procurement shall be based on economy and efficiency. If used, the interagency agreement shall stipulate who is authorized to purchase on behalf of the participating parties and shall specify inspection, acceptance, termination, payment, and other relevant terms and conditions. The county board of commissioners may use federal or state excess and surplus property instead of purchasing new equipment and property if feasible and if it will result in a reduction of project costs. (Code 1987, § 2-103; Ord. No. 2010-007, § 3.3.0, 7-6-2010) Sec. 2-102. - Independent cost estimate (ICE). For all purchases above the micro purchase threshold, the county board of commissioners shall prepare an independent cost estimate (ICE) prior to solicitation. The details shall be commensurate with the cost and complexity of the purchase. (Code 1987, § 2-104; Ord. No. 2010-007, § 3.4.0, 7-6-2010) Sec. 2-103. - Cost and price analysis. The county board of commissioners shall require assurance that, before entering into a contract, the price is reasonable, in accordance with the following instructions: (1) Petty cash and micro purchases. No formal cost or price analysis is required. Rather, the execution of a contract by the county administrator or designee (through a purchase order or other means) shall serve as the county administrator's determination that the price obtained is reasonable, which may be based on the county administrator's or designee's prior experience or other factors. (2) Small purchases. A comparison with other offers shall generally be sufficient determination of the reasonableness of price and no further analysis is required. If a reasonable number of quotes is not obtained to establish reasonableness through price competition, the county administrator or designee shall document price reasonableness through other means, such as prior purchases of this nature, catalog prices, the county administrator or designee's personal knowledge at the time of purchase, comparison to the ICE, or any other reasonable basis. (3) Sealed bids. The presence of adequate competition should generally be sufficient to establish price reasonableness. Where sufficient bids are not received, and when the bid received is substantially more than the ICE, and where the county board of commissioners cannot reasonably determine price reasonableness, the county board of commissioners must conduct a cost analysis, consistent with federal guidelines, to ensure that the price paid is reasonable, and if the bid is found not to be reasonable in the opinion of the board of commissioners, the bid can be rejected. (4) Competitive proposals. The presence of adequate competition should generally be sufficient to establish price reasonableness. Where sufficient proposals are not received (generally three or more), the county board of commissioners must compare the selected proposer's cost estimate with the ICE. For competitive proposals where costs or prices cannot be easily compared among the firms that have submitted proposals, where there is not adequate competition, or where the proposed cost or price is substantially greater than the ICE, the county board of commissioners must conduct a cost analysis, consistent with federal guidelines, to ensure that the price paid is reasonable, and if the bid is found not to be reasonable in the opinion of the board of commissioners, the proposal can be rejected. (5) Contract modifications. A cost analysis, consistent with federal guidelines, shall be conducted for all contract modifications for projects that were procured through sealed bids, competitive proposals, or noncompetitive proposals, or for projects originally procured through small purchase procedures and the amount of the contract modification will result in a total contract price in excess of $100,000.00. Such modifications shall require the approval of the governing board. (Code 1987, § 2-105; Ord. No. 2010-007, § 3.5.0, 7-6-2010) Sec. 2-104. - Solicitation and advertising. (a) Method of solicitation. (1) Petty cash and micro purchases. The county board of commissioners may contact only one source if the price is considered reasonable. (2) Small purchases. Quotes may be solicited orally, through fax, or by any other reasonable method. (3) Sealed bids and competitive proposals. Solicitation must be done publicly. The county board of commissioners must use one or more following solicitation methods, provided that the method employed provides for meaningful competition: a. Advertising in newspapers or other print mediums of local or general circulations. b. Advertising in various trade journals or publications or web sites. c. E-procurement. The county board of commissioners may conduct its public procurements through the Internet using e-procurement systems. However, all procurements must otherwise be in compliance with 24 CFR 85.36, state and local requirements, and the county board of commissioners' procurement policy. d. For acquisition of professional services when a "request for proposals" is used, the commission may require prequalification of consultants or contractors. The commission may base prequalification on firms meeting the state criteria. (4) Request for qualifications. Solicitation must be done publicly. The county board of commissioners must use one or more following solicitation methods, provided that the method employed provides for meaningful competition: a. Advertising in newspapers or other print mediums of local or general circulations. b. Advertising in various trade journals or publications or web sites. c. For acquisition of professional services when a "request for qualifications" is used, the commission may require prequalification of consultants or contractors. The commission may base prequalification on firms meeting the state criteria. (b) Time frame. For purchases of more than $25,000.00, public notice should run not less than once each week for two consecutive weeks. (c) Form. Notices/advertisements should state, at a minimum, the place, date, and time that the bids or proposals are due, the solicitation number, a contact person that can provide a copy of, and information about, the solicitation, and a brief description of the needed items. (d) Time period for submission of bids. A minimum of 30 days shall generally be provided for preparation and submission of sealed bids and 15 days for competitive proposals. However, the county administrator may allow for a shorter period under extraordinary circumstances. (e) Cancellation of solicitations. The solicitation of bids or proposals may be cancelled before bids or proposals are due if, in the opinion of the county administrator, the items or services are no longer needed, or if there are errors in the solicitation process. (Code 1987, § 2-106; Ord. No. 2010-007, § 3.6.0, 7-6-2010) Sec. 2-105. - Contract pricing arrangements; contract types. Any type of contract which is appropriate to the procurement and which will promote the best interests of the county board of commissioners may be used. All solicitations and contracts shall include the clauses and provisions necessary to define the rights and responsibilities of both the contractor and the county board of commissioners. (Code 1987, § 2-107; Ord. No. 2010-007, § 3.7.0, 7-6-2010) Sec. 2-106. - Contract clauses. All contracts should identify the contract pricing arrangement as well as other pertinent terms and conditions, as determined by the county board of commissioners. (Code 1987, § 2-108; Ord. No. 2010-007, § 3.8.0, 7-6-2010) Sec. 2-107. - Contract administration. The county board of commissioners shall maintain a system of contract administration designed to ensure that contractors perform in accordance with their contracts. These systems shall provide for inspection of supplies, services, or construction, as well as monitoring contractor performance, status reporting on major projects including construction contracts, and similar matters. For cost-reimbursement contracts, costs are allowable only to the extent that they are consistent with accepted cost principals. The commission may withhold ten percent of the amount requested in each request for reimbursement until of all work and products are delivered and approved by the county administrator. (Code 1987, § 2-109; Ord. No. 2010-007, § 3.9.0, 7-6-2010) Sec. 2-108. - Assistance to small and other businesses; required efforts. Consistent with Presidential Executive Orders 11625, 12138, and 12432, and Section 3 of the Federal Act of 1968, all feasible efforts shall be made to ensure that small and minority owned businesses, women's business enterprises, and other individuals or firms located in or owned in substantial part by persons residing in the area of the county board of commissioners' project are used when possible. (Code 1987, § 2-110; Ord. No. 2010-007, § 3.10.0, 7-6-2010) Sec. 2-109. - Governing board approval of procurement actions. All contracts where the base contract amount or any option exceeds $100,000.00 are required to be preapproved by the governing board. In addition, all contract modifications that will bring the total amount of the contract in excess of $100,000.00 require preapproval by the governing board. (Code 1987, § 2-111; Ord. No. 2010-007, § 3.11.0, 7-6-2010) Sec. 2-110. - Delegation of contracting to county board of commissioners. While the county administrator is responsible for ensuring that the county board of commissioners' procurements comply with this policy, the county administrator may delegate all procurements to the county board of commissioners as is necessary and appropriate to conduct the business of the agency. Further, and in accordance with this delegation of county board of commissioners, the county administrator shall, where necessary, establish operational procedures (such as a procurement manual or standard operating procedures) to implement this policy. (Code 1987, § 2-112; Ord. No. 2010-007, § 3.12.0, 7-6-2010) Sec. 2-111. - Documentation. (a) The county board of commissioners must maintain records sufficient to detail the significant history of each procurement action. These records shall include, but not necessarily be limited to, the following: (1) Rationale for the method of procurement (if not self-evident); (2) Rationale of contract pricing arrangement (also if not self-evident); (3) Reason for accepting or rejecting the bids or offers; (4) Basis for the contract price; (5) A copy of the contract documents awarded or issued and signed by the executive director; (6) Basis for contract modifications; and (7) Related contract administration actions. (b) The level of documentation should be commensurate with the value of the procurement. Records are to be retained for a period of three years after final payment and all matters pertaining to the contact are closed. (Code 1987, § 2-113; Ord. No. 2010-007, § 3.13.0, 7-6-2010) Sec. 2-112. - Disposition of surplus property. Property no longer necessary for the county board of commissioners' purposes (non-real property) shall be transferred, sold, or disposed of as determined by the county administrator and/or applicable state law. Real property (with estimated remaining value exceeding $500.00) will be transferred, sold, or disposed of as directed by the county administrator. (Code 1987, § 2-114; Ord. No. 2010-007, § 3.14.0, 7-6-2010) Sec. 2-113. - Funding availability. Before initiating any contract, the county board of commissioners and/or the county administrator shall ensure that there are sufficient funds available to cover the anticipated cost of the contract or modification. (Code 1987, § 2-115; Ord. No. 2010-007, § 3.15.0, 7-6-2010) Sec. 2-114. - Self-certification. The county board of commissioners self-certifies that this procurement policy, and the county board of commissioners' procurement system, complies with all applicable federal regulations. (Code 1987, § 2-116; Ord. No. 2010-007, § 3.16.0, 7-6-2010)

div.head: Chapter 4 - ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Georgia Alcoholic Beverage Code, O.C.G.A. § 3-1-1 et seq.; county governing authority given power to regulate alcoholic beverages permitting and licensing, O.C.G.A. § 3-3-2; governing authority of county has power to locally regulate, license, and tax the manufacturing, distribution and selling of malt beverages, O.C.G.A. §§ 3-5-40 et seq. and 3-5-80 et seq.; governing authority of county has power to locally regulate, license, and tax the manufacturing, distribution and selling of wine, O.C.G.A. §§ 3-6-40 et seq. and 3-6-60 et seq.; governing authority of county has power to locally regulate, license, and tax the manufacturing, distribution and selling of distilled spirits by the package, O.C.G.A. §§ 3-4-40 et seq. and 3-4-80; local government may authorize issuance license to sell distilled spirits by the drink for consumption on premises where sold, O.C.G.A. § 3-4-90 et seq.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 4-1. - Definitions. (a) The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Licensee means a person holding a license to engage in the sale of alcoholic beverages for consumption on the premises by the drink or for consumption off the premises (package), as the case may be. Premises means the definite closed or partitioned-in locality, whether room, shop or building wherein alcoholic beverages are sold by the drink, or are sold for consumption off the premises (package), as the case may be. (b) The definitions set forth in O.C.G.A. § 3-1-2 ("Alcoholic Beverages—Definitions") shall be effective as definitions of the words, terms and phrases used in this chapter. All words, terms and phrases used herein, other than those specifically defined elsewhere in this chapter, shall have the respective meanings ascribed to them in O.C.G.A. § 3-1-2, and shall have the same scope and effect that the same words, terms and phrases have where used in O.C.G.A. § 3-1-2. (Code 1987, § 4-1; Res. of 10-4-1977(1), § 1; Res. of 10-4-1977(2), § 1) Sec. 4-2. - Applicability in unincorporated areas only. This article shall apply to the unincorporated areas of the county only. (Code 1987, § 4-2; Res. of 10-4-1977(1), § 38; Res. of 10-4-1977(2), § 34) Sec. 4-3. - Proper license required. (a) It shall be unlawful for any person to sell alcoholic beverages for use or consumption on the premises without the license required herein. (b) It shall be unlawful for any person to sell alcoholic beverages for use or consumption off the premises without the license required herein. (Code 1987, § 4-3; Res. of 10-4-1977(1), § 33; Res. of 10-4-1977(2), § 29) Sec. 4-4. - License application forms; furnishing data; producing witnesses. The governing authority of the county shall prescribe forms for new or renewal applications hereunder. All applicants shall furnish all data, information and records requested of them by the governing authority of the county and failure to furnish such data, information and records within 30 days from the date of such request shall automatically serve to dismiss, with prejudice, the application. Applicants, by filing an application, agree to produce for oral interrogation any persons requested by the governing authority of the county. Failure to produce such persons within 30 days after being requested to do so shall result in the automatic dismissal of such application. (Code 1987, § 4-5; Res. of 10-4-1977(1), § 28; Res. of 10-4-1977(2), § 24) Sec. 4-5. - State laws applicable. All applicable state laws, rules and regulations governing sale of alcoholic beverages shall be complied with by any applicant for a license hereunder. (Code 1987, § 4-6; Res. of 10-4-1977(1), § 35; Res. of 10-4-1977(2), § 31) Sec. 4-6. - False statements. Any untrue or misleading information contained in or material omission in an original, renewal or transfer application for a license hereunder shall be cause for the denial thereof, and, if any license has been granted under these circumstances, same shall be cause for the revocation of same. (Code 1987, § 4-7; Res. of 10-4-1977(2), § 25) Sec. 4-7. - Factors considered in issuing licenses. In determining whether or not any license applied for hereunder shall be granted, in addition to all provisions of this article, the following shall be considered in the public interest and welfare: (1) The applicant's reputation, character, mental and physical capacity to conduct this business. (2) If applicant is a previous holder of a license to sell alcoholic beverages, whether or not applicant has violated any law, regulation or ordinance relating to such business. (3) If applicant is a previous holder of a license to sell alcoholic beverages, the manner in which applicant conducted the business thereunder as to the necessity for unusual police observation and inspection in order to prevent the violation of any law, regulation or ordinance relating to such business. (4) The location for which the license is sought as to traffic congestion, general character of neighborhood, and the effect such an establishment would have on the adjacent and surrounding property values. (5) The number of licenses already granted for similar businesses in the trading area of the place for which the license is sought. (6) Whether applicant is a person whose license issued under the police powers of any governmental entity has been previously suspended or revoked. (Code 1987, § 4-8; Res. of 10-4-1977(1), § 5; Res. of 10-4-1977(2), § 5) Sec. 4-8. - Conviction of commission of crime. No original license shall be issued to any person where any individual having an interest either as owner, partner, principal stockholder, directly or indirectly beneficial or absolute, or such individual's spouse, shall have been convicted or shall have taken a plea of nolo contendere within ten years immediately prior to the filing of said application for any felony or misdemeanor of any state or of the United States or any municipal ordinance or county ordinance or resolution except traffic violations; the term "conviction" shall include an adjudication of guilt or a plea of guilty or nolo contendere or the forfeiture of a bond when charged with a crime; where the violation is for a misdemeanor, forfeiture of bond or municipal ordinance or county ordinance or resolution, the board of commissioners, after investigation, may waive the same as a disqualification. (Code 1987, § 4-9; Res. of 10-4-1977(1), § 6; Res. of 10-4-1977(2), § 6) Sec. 4-9. - Citizenship requirement; compliance by partners and stockholders. No license hereunder shall be granted to any applicant who is not a citizen of the United States. Where the applicant is a corporation, the principal stockholder must meet the requirements of this article and the license shall be issued to the corporation and the principal stockholder. If the applicant is a partnership, the requirements of this chapter shall apply to all partners. (Code 1987, § 4-10; Res. of 10-4-1977(1), § 7; Res. of 10-4-1977(2), § 7) Sec. 4-10. - Reading of chapter required. No person shall be approved for a license hereunder, or approved for employment by a licensee, unless such person shall have read these regulations in full text and certify in writing the fact of such reading and knowledge thereof. (Code 1987, § 4-11; Res. of 10-4-1977(1), § 36; Res. of 10-4-1977(2), § 32) Sec. 4-11. - Display of copy of article. It shall be the duty of the management of the premises licensed hereunder to maintain a copy of this article on such premises and to instruct each employee of the terms thereof. (Code 1987, § 4-12; Res. of 10-4-1977(1), § 32; Res. of 10-4-1977(2), § 28) Sec. 4-12. - License fees. An annual license fee as hereinafter set out shall be charged for the initial license issued to any licensee hereunder, and a like amount for each renewal license. All license fees hereunder shall be paid in advance on or before December 31 of each year and for any new license granted hereunder during a calendar year there shall be paid the full license fee without proration. The amount for said annual license fees shall be as follows: (1) Distilled spirits (consumption on the premises): $1,200.00; (2) Malt beverages (consumption on the premises): $300.00; (3) Wine (consumption on the premises); $200.00; (4) Distilled spirits (consumption off the premises): $1,200.00; (5) Malt beverages (consumption off the premises): $300.00; and (6) Wine (consumption off the premises): $200.00. (Code 1987, § 4-13; Res. of 10-4-1977(1), § 8; Res. of 10-4-1977(2), § 8; Mo. of 11-3-1992; Mo. of 7-6-1993) Sec. 4-13. - Delinquent license charge. There shall be collected a ten percent penalty on all delinquent alcoholic beverage licenses. (Code 1987, § 4-14; Ord. of 1-5-1960(2)) Sec. 4-14. - Fee for investigation and report. Each application for license under this article shall be accompanied by a certified check or cash for the full amount of the license fee, together with a separate check or cash to defray the cost of the investigation and report. If the application is denied and the license refused, the deposit representing the license fee shall be refunded, but the investigation and report payment shall be retained as the cost of filing and processing the application. The fees described in this provision shall be in amounts as established by the board of commissioners from time to time. (Code 1987, § 4-15; Res. of 10-4-1977(1), § 34; Res. of 10-4-1977(2), § 30) Sec. 4-15. - Time for obtaining original licenses. All new licenses must be obtained and fees paid not later than two weeks from the date of the approval of the application and if not so obtained, the permit shall be void. (Code 1987, § 4-16; Res. of 10-4-1977(1), § 20; Res. of 10-4-1977(2), § 16) Sec. 4-16. - Minimum size of containers in on-premises consumption establishments. The holder of an on-premises consumption license may purchase from wholesalers licensed by the state alcoholic beverages in sizes of one-fifth of a gallon or larger containers unless a particular brand is not packaged in these size contents, and then said license holders may purchase said brand in the nearest size to said minimum size containers. (Code 1987, § 4-17; Res. of 10-4-1977(1), § 9) Sec. 4-17. - Sale by the drink at package store. Off-premises consumption licensees hereunder shall not permit the sale of alcoholic beverages by the drink. (Code 1987, § 4-18; Res. of 10-4-1977(2), § 9) Sec. 4-18. - Sale by the package in lounges. On-premises consumption licensees hereunder shall not permit the sale of alcoholic beverages by the bottle or package, except that wines, champagnes and malt beverages may be sold by the bottle or package for consumption on the premises. (Code 1987, § 4-19; Res. of 10-4-1977(1), § 10) Sec. 4-19. - Cleanliness of premises; obscene acts, etc. (a) All premises shall be kept clean and in proper sanitary condition and in full compliance with the provisions and regulations governing the conditions of premises used for storage and sale of food for human consumption. (b) It shall be unlawful to permit any disturbance of the peace or obscenity or any lewd, immoral or improper entertainment, conduct or practices. (Code 1987, § 4-20; Res. of 10-4-1977(1), § 2; Res. of 10-4-1977(2), § 2) Sec. 4-20. - Sale to minors or incapacitated persons. No license holder shall sell or give away, or permit the sale or gift to, or the procuring for, any alcoholic beverages to any person under legal drinking age, as defined by state law, to any person who is mentally incompetent, or to any person who is physically or mentally incapacitated due to the consumption of distilled spirits or alcoholic beverages. (Code 1987, § 4-21; Res. of 10-4-1977(1), § 3; Res. of 10-4-1977(2), § 3) Sec. 4-21. - Drinking or possessing by minor. It shall be unlawful for any person under legal drinking age, as defined by state law, to drink or possess any alcoholic beverage. (Code 1987, § 4-22; Res. of 10-4-1977(1), § 4; Res. of 10-4-1977(2), § 4) Sec. 4-22. - Hours of sale. (a) Except as authorized under section 4-42, no licensee engaged in the sale of alcoholic beverages for consumption on the premises shall sell, give away or otherwise distribute alcoholic beverages between the hours of 11:45 p.m. Saturday and 8:00 a.m. Monday and between the hours of 2:45 a.m. and 8:00 a.m. on other days. (b) No licensee engaged in the sale of distilled spirits for consumption off the premises shall sell, give away or otherwise dispense alcoholic beverages, except between the hours of 12:30 p.m. and 11:30 p.m. on Sundays and between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 11:45 p.m. on other days. (c) There shall be no restricted hours of sale for any licensee engaged in the sale of wine and/or malt beverages (but not distilled spirits) for consumption off the premises, except that, on Sundays, said licensee shall only sell, give away or otherwise dispense wine and/or malt beverages between the hours of 12:30 p.m. and 11:30 p.m. (Code 1987, § 4-23; Res. of 10-4-1977(1), § 11; Res. of 10-4-1977(2), § 10; Ord. No. 2008-001, § I(1), 8-5-2008; Res. of 7-21-2016, § 2) Sec. 4-23. - Diluting beverage; misrepresenting quality, quantity, and brand. It shall be illegal for licensees hereunder to add to the contents of a bottle or to refill empty bottles or in any other manner to misrepresent the quantity, quality or brand name of any alcoholic beverage. (Code 1987, § 4-24; Res. of 10-4-1977(1), § 12; Res. of 10-4-1977(2), § 11) Sec. 4-24. - Display of prices in lounges. All on-premises consumption licensees hereunder shall display in prominent places on the premises their current prices of spirituous liquors, wines, champagnes and malt beverages by the drink. (Code 1987, § 4-25; Res. of 10-4-1977(1), § 13) Sec. 4-25. - Sale off the premises. It shall be unlawful for any sales to be made outside of the building, premises or place of business licensed for such sale. (Code 1987, § 4-26; Res. of 10-4-1977(1), § 15; Res. of 10-4-1977(2), § 13) Sec. 4-26. - License period; no refunds. No license shall issue for less than a calendar year period, or the remainder thereof, and in case of the revocation or surrender of such license before the expiration of such calendar year period, the holder thereof shall not be entitled to receive any refund whatsoever. (Code 1987, § 4-27; Res. of 10-4-1977(1), § 16; Res. of 10-4-1977(2), § 14) Sec. 4-27. - Sale on election day.
