(c) If any of the matter or material dumped in violation of the provisions of subsection (a) of this section can be identified as having last belonged to, been in the possession of, sent to or received by, or to have been the property of any person prior to its being dumped as prohibited herein, this identification shall be presumed to be prima facie evidence that the owner dumped or caused to be dumped such matter and material in violation of this chapter. (d) For information leading to the arrest and conviction of any person violating the provisions of this chapter or the provisions of any state law prohibiting the dumping of garbage, refuse, or litter on any public or private property within the county, the board may, in its discretion, pay a reward in the amount established by action of the board of commissioners, a copy of which is on file in the office of the county administrator, to the person furnishing such information leading to such arrest and conviction and such monies as may be a necessary cost of the operation and administration of the county government. (e) All compactors containing combustible materials emptied at a county disposal facility will pay the price per ton established in section 34-45. These fees may be changed from time to time by resolution of the governing authority of the county. (f) No person shall place any accumulations of refuse or trash in any street, median, alley, or other public place or travel, nor upon any private property except with the written consent of the property owner thereof and then only in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. (g) No person shall place any refuse, trash, refuse receptacle or container on, over, or near any storm drain or drainage, ditches, or so close thereto as to cause such material to interfere in any way with such drainage. (h) Any accumulation of refuse or trash items on any lot, property, premises, public streets, alley or other public or private place not permitted by this article is hereby declared to be a public nuisance. Failure of the owner or occupant to remove and correct any such accumulation of refuse after appropriate notice from the county shall raise the presumption that such person intended to violate the article. (i) It shall be unlawful for any person to place or leave outside any building or dwelling except as specified in this subsection any dilapidated furniture, appliance, machinery, equipment, building material, junked motor vehicle, or other items which is either in a partially rusted, wrecked, junked, dismantled, or inoperative condition, and which is not completely enclosed within a building or dwelling. Any such item or items which remain on the property of the occupant for a period of 30 days after notice of violation of this section, shall be presumed to be abandoned and subject to being removed from the property by the county without further notice. The county may charge the owner or occupant a fee for the cost of removing said item or items. This section shall not apply to licensed junk dealers or currently licensed establishments engaged in the repair, rebuilding, reconditioning or salvaging of equipment or furniture. (j) It shall be unlawful for any person to leave outside any building in a place accessible to children any appliance, refrigerator, or other container which has an airtight snap lock or similar device without first removing therefrom the lock or door. This section shall not apply to any appliances, refrigerators or container which has been placed on or adjacent to the rear of the building and which has been crated, strapped or locked so that it will be impossible for a child to obtain access to any compartment thereof. (k) No person other than the owner thereof or an agent or employee of the county/municipality shall disturb or interfere with any container used for the purpose of storing refuse pending the collection, or remove any contents therefrom or remove such container from its location. (Code 1987, § 15-4; Ord. of 11-3-1992) Sec. 34-5. - Operation of private landfills. No landfill or disposal facility shall be operated within the county without written approval of the county and maintenance of the required permit as issued by the state (NDR-EPD). (Code 1987, § 15-5; Ord. of 11-3-1992) Sec. 34-6. - Biomedical waste. Biomedical wastes will be governed as prescribed in Ga. Comp. R. and Regs. § 391-3-4-.15, "Biomedical Waste," of the Act or any revision hereof. (Code 1987, § 15-6; Ord. of 11-3-1992) Sec. 34-7. - Asbestos-containing waste. (a) No asbestos-containing waste, either friable or nonfriable, will be accepted for disposal at any disposal facility operated under the jurisdiction of the county. (b) Asbestos waste generated in the jurisdictional area of the county will be handled, stored, transported, and disposed of as regulated by the state. (Code 1987, § 15-7; Ord. of 11-3-1992) Sec. 34-8. - Petroleum-contaminated soils. (a) No petroleum-contaminated soils will be disposed of at any disposal site operated under the jurisdiction of the county. (b) Petroleum-contaminated soils generated in the jurisdictional area of the county will be handled, stored, transported, and disposed of as regulated by the state. (Code 1987, § 15-8; Ord. of 11-3-1992) Sec. 34-9. - Tires. (a) No inflatable tire will be disposed of at any landfill operated in the jurisdictional area of the county. (b) Tires will be accepted for disposal at the county solid waste disposal facility under the fee structure established elsewhere in this chapter. Fees are applicable to all generators of waste tires. (c) All tire vendors operating in the county are required to maintain records describing the receipt, sale, and disposal of each tire processed through their individual operation. These records shall detail an audit trail of all used tires through disposal and are to include accurate receipts for disposal, such as billings for disposal from a used tire vendor, processor, solid waste handling facility, or individual customer who chooses to accept such waste tires. Disposal receipts will include the name, address and telephone number of the recipient; the quantity, make, serial number and size of each tire disposed of; and the date of disposal. Such records will be available for public inspection at any time. (Code 1987, § 15-9; Ord. of 11-3-1992) Sec. 34-10. - Lead acid batteries. (a) No person may place a lead acid vehicle battery in any waste collection container located in the jurisdictional area of the county, or discard, or otherwise dispose of a lead acid vehicle battery, except by delivery to a battery retailer or wholesaler, to a secondary lead smelter, or to a collector or recovered materials processing facility that accepts lead acid batteries. (b) Battery wholesalers and retailers are required to post and maintain, in a conspicuous place, the lead acid vehicle battery notice as required by O.C.G.A. § 12-8-28(c)(2). (Code 1987, § 15-10) Secs. 34-11—34-38. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - COUNTY COLLECTION AND DISPOSAL SERVICE
Sec. 34-39. - Notice to owner, occupant of unacceptable container or area. The county, upon determining that a can, container or area is becoming or has become unserviceable or unsanitary or likely to cause an unsanitary condition, shall issue a notice to the owner or occupant of the premises upon which the can, container or condition exists to inform such person of the condition existing. Failure of the owner/occupant to correct the condition shall cause removal of the container at the established fee structure. (Code 1987, § 15-26; Ord. of 11-3-1992) Sec. 34-40. - Pickup routes and districts established. (a) County convenience centers. The county shall divide the unincorporated areas of the county into pickup routes and convenience center locations. The routes and convenience center locations shall be plainly outlined on a map of the county and numbered alpha-numerically. The county shall prepare a list of the names of all streets, roads, alleys, drives, highways, and other public thoroughfares which form each route; shall keep the map and list for public inspection; and shall furnish a copy of the map showing any particular route and convenience center along with a list of names of the public thoroughfares therein to any person who requests them upon the payment of the actual cost for the reproduction of the map and list by either a county or commercial facility, whichever is available. (b) Commercial container sites. The county shall develop commercial collection route maps, showing each commercial/multiple-dwelling unit serviced by county collection. Where practical, self-contained compaction units will be used for the bulk container collection of commercial refuse. The remainder of the service to commercial/multiple-dwelling unit establishments will be accomplished with four to eight cubic yard containers. The route map will show the location of each commercial container, alpha-numerically coded to designate the route, the frequency of weekly collection, the type and number of containers, and the customer account number. As with the residential route maps, these route maps will be available for public inspection and purchase at the cost of administrative reproduction. (Code 1987, § 15-27; Ord. of 11-3-1992) Sec. 34-41. - Preparation and storage of residential refuse for collection; placement at convenience centers; unacceptable refuse. The county will operate appropriate convenience centers approved by the board of commissioners. Normally, a convenience center will provide bulk collection containers for household solid waste (putrescible); recyclables; yard waste on a specified scheduled basis; and large household items such as furniture and appliances on a specified scheduled basis. Each convenience center will have posted the hours of operation. It shall be the duty of the occupant or owner of any private residential unit to properly maintain all refuse pending disposal at one of the county-operated convenience centers or to transport such refuse to the county-operated sanitary landfill, dry trash landfill, transfer station or other private disposal facility as herein defined. (1) All residential garbage shall be free of liquid and placed in watertight paper or plastic bags and the tops secured and placed in appropriate waste containers at designated county convenience centers. (2) All county residents governed by these regulations will be encouraged, through educational programs and community pride, to participate in the county recycling program. Each resident is encouraged to separate recyclables from residential waste prior to disposal and to voluntarily deposit recyclables at the nearest convenience center. (3) Other household refuse, less recyclables, will be containerized where practical and disposed of at one of the county convenience centers based upon the posted hours. Such refuse will not be disposed of at any convenience center unless the designated type of refuse container is available at the center. Refuse improperly deposited will be classified as litter and handled as regulated herein. (4) Household yard wastes will be accepted at convenience centers; however, such waste shall not exceed four feet in length nor be any larger than four inches in diameter. Such yard waste shall fit into the available container. Yard waste improperly deposited at any county facility shall be treated as litter and handled as regulated herein. (5) Each owner shall prevent the continued, excessive and unsightly accumulation of refuse upon the property such person occupies or the public thoroughfares adjoining the property. (6) It shall be unlawful to place or cause to be placed in any refuse collection container any lead acid or mercury battery, engine or hydraulic oils, explosive material, flammable liquid, inflatable rubber tires of any size, liquid in excess of one U.S. gallon, or dangerous or corrosive material of any kind. (Disposal of such materials shall be coordinated with the clean community coordinator.) (7) Inoperative, privately used, worn-out household appliances (refrigerators, stoves, washing machines, dryers, freezers, air conditioners, furniture) will be collected at convenience centers on specified dates. (8) Household waste (yard, appliances, construction debris) generated by a private single residence may be delivered directly to the county-operated sanitary landfill or the transfer station at no charge to the resident. (9) Commercial or construction waste generated from the conduct of business or commercial enterprise carried on from or at private residential units will not be disposed of at county convenience centers. Such waste shall be disposed of as commercial or construction waste as regulated elsewhere in this chapter. (Code 1987, § 15-28; Ord. of 11-3-1992) Sec. 34-42. - Preparation and storage of commercial and multiple-dwelling refuse for collection: unacceptable refuse. (a) All commercial establishments, condominiums, and townhouses within the county shall be required to provide for commercial collection/disposal of all solid waste, except for recyclables, when no recycling container is provided at such locations. It shall be unlawful for commercially generated waste to be disposed of at any county-operated convenience center. (b) Before a building permit shall be issued for construction of a public or commercial establishment, condominium, or townhouse complex, arrangements for the storage, collection, and transportation of the required commercial container must be approved by the county sanitation supervisor. (c) Commercial containers at existing commercial establishments and multiple-dwelling units shall be placed at locations approved by the county. The county will not collect refuse from commercial establishments or multiple-dwelling units unless it is placed in commercial containers, properly located. Uncontaminated cardboard boxes shall be cleaned of all noncardboard/paper packing materials, flattened and placed in available cardboard recycling containers. It shall be unlawful for any commercial establishment to dispose of refuse in green boxes marked for residential refuse only. (d) Where the occupants of two or more commercial establishments share the use of a refuse container, it shall be the joint responsibility of the users to maintain the area surrounding such container clean and free of accumulations of refuse. (e) The occupant or occupants of nonresidential commercial establishments and the management of multiple-dwelling units and residential commercial establishments serviced by commercial containers shall be responsible for maintaining the area surrounding such commercial containers clean and free of accumulations of refuse. (f) All garbage and rubbish generated at commercial or residential commercial establishments shall be free of liquid and placed in watertight paper or plastic bags with tops secured prior to placement in commercial containers. (g) A handling fee will be charged on any commercial containers containing any of the following items: (1) Large household or industrial appliances. (2) Furniture. (3) Tires. (4) Wooden crates. (5) Logs or limbs over four feet in length or four inches in diameter. (6) Bed springs. (7) Rock, dirt, concrete blocks, etc. (8) Uncontainable garbage, yard debris, and household trash. (9) Asbestos or asbestos-containing materials. (10) Any liquid in excess of one U.S. gallon. (h) Normal household appliances will be collected on a special fee basis at residential commercial establishments and multiple-dwellings served by commercial containers, when placed adjacent to the container and after prior coordination with the county sanitation department supervisor. (i) It shall be unlawful to place or cause to be placed in any refuse collection container any lead acid or mercury battery, engine or hydraulic oils, explosive material, flammable liquid, inflatable rubber tire of any size, liquid in excess of one U.S. gallon, or dangerous or corrosive material of any kind. (Disposal of such materials shall be coordinated with the clean community coordinator.) (j) All loading and unloading areas shall be provided with refuse receptacles for loose debris, paper, packaging materials and other trash. The owner or occupant of the commercial establishment or multidwelling unit shall place a sufficient number of containers in said area to maintain a clean, neat, and sanitary condition at all times. (k) All parking lots and establishments with parking lots shall provide refuse receptacles within the parking area. Such receptacles shall be weighed or attached to the ground as necessary to prevent spillage. It shall be the responsibility of the owner or his agent to collect the refuse and trash deposited in such containers and store this material in a location until collected by the county. The sanitation department supervisor shall have the authority to determine the number and types of receptacles necessary to provide property containerization. (l) It shall be the obligation of all persons using the parking areas to place any trash or litter in receptacles or containers, and it shall be unlawful for any person to dump, scatter or throw on any parking lot, any refuse, garbage or trash of any kind. (m) All construction and demolition contractors shall provide on-site refuse receptacles, bulk containers or detachable containers for the collection of loose debris, paper, building material waste, scrap building materials, and other trash produced by those working at the construction/demolition site. All such sites shall be kept in a litter-free condition. The number and size of the containers will be determined by the volume of refuse generated and the size of the site. Dirt, mud, construction materials, or other debris upon any public or private property belonging to a person other than the owner of the construction site shall be removed by the contractor upon completion of the construction. (Code 1987, § 15-29; Ord. of 11-3-1992) Sec. 34-43. - Collection of refuse generally; conditions of collection by the county. (a) Refuse may be collected for disposal by the county by municipalities, or by persons or commercial sanitation firms licensed by the state and either the county or municipality for which the service is contracted. (b) The county and its licensed scavengers will collect refuse under the following conditions: (1) Convenience centers for residential (noncommercial) county residents. a. Refuse will be collected from county-operated convenience centers at least weekly. Collection frequency will be determined by the volume or refuse disposed of at each center. b. Recycling containers will be spotted at each convenience center on a scheduled weekly basis. These containers will accept recyclables such as glass, plastic, and aluminum. c. A newspaper recycling container will be available at each center on a continuous basis. d. Containers for yard waste and white goods, furniture, and large bulky items of residential use will be spotted at each convenience center on a scheduled weekly basis. e. Dead animals, regardless of size, will not be collected at convenience centers. Dead animals (household pets) will be disposed of at the animal shelter. Large dead animals shall be disposed of by burial on the individual's property to whom the animal belongs. The county has no responsibility to supply service for the removal and disposal of large dead animals. f. The county shall not be responsible for the collection or hauling of discarded building materials, dirt, rock, discarded furniture, or appliances from private property, nor shall it be responsible for collecting or hauling trees, bushes, other vegetation or debris generated from commercial or residential occupant tree trimming, landscaping, or construction activities. (2) Commercial and multiple-dwelling units. a. Refuse will be collected as often as seven times per week. Frequency of pickup will be determined by the county sanitation department supervisor and the local health department based on generation volumes, available container capacity, container type, and type of refuse. b. Commercial establishments choosing to recycle specific items will containerize the recyclables as specified in the recycling agreement. Recyclables will be collected at least weekly. (Code 1987, § 15-30; Ord. of 11-3-1992) Sec. 34-44. - Statements and payments for county collection services. The board of commissioners recommends monthly billings of all accounts. (Code 1987, § 15-31; Ord. of 11-3-1992) Sec. 34-45. - Fee schedule for county collection and disposal services. (a) The solid waste management fees will be charged based on the service provided and shall be in amounts as established by the board of commissioners from time to time. (b) Municipalities that provide collection services will be charged on a per-ton basis for the amount of waste disposed. The total fee for municipalities providing collection will be per-ton and in an amount as established by the board of commissioners from time to time. (c) The unincorporated areas of the county and municipalities that do not provide collection will be charged based on a per capita basis for collection and disposal instead of tipping fees. This includes municipalities that provide collection but also have county-maintained dumpsters within their city limits which are used for residential customers. This fee is based on per capita which is a pro-rata share of the fees and will be in an amount as established by the board of commissioners from time to time. (d) Contractors who deliver waste to the county landfill or transfer station will be charged the same as municipalities providing collection. (e) Charges for disposal of yard waste will be on a per-ton basis. The fees for disposal of yard waste shall be in an amount as established by the board of commissioners from time to time. (f) Charges for disposal of building construction material will be on a per-ton basis. The fees for disposal of building construction material shall be in amounts as established by the board of commissioners from time to time. (g) Charges for disposal of white goods will be on a per-ton basis. The fees for disposal of white goods shall be in amounts as established by the board of commissioners from time to time. (Code 1987, § 15-32; Ord. of 11-3-1992) Secs. 34-46—34-63. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - FEES
Sec. 34-64. - General coverage of costs. (a) The full costs of providing all or a portion of the residential solid waste services in the county shall be recovered from the citizens thereof, who benefit from the availability of county provided services, in the form of a solid waste assessment and/or a solid waste tipping fee. The solid waste cost components include collection of residential putrescible and bulk waste, disposal of residential putrescible and bulk waste, transfer station operations, debt service, recycling, landfill closure and post closure maintenance, litter control, polycart service where provided, and the "Keep Liberty Beautiful" program. (b) The revenue derived from the solid waste assessment shall be set to cover the costs of solid waste services provided to the respective tax districts of the county. (c) The solid waste tipping fees shall be set to cover the full costs of the county waste disposal. (d) The amount to be charged as the solid waste assessment and the solid waste tipping fees shall be established and adjusted as necessary by the county board of commissioners, and shall appear in the official minutes of the board meeting at which the charges are adopted by resolution. At that time, they shall constitute a fee schedule and become attached to this article. (Code 1987, § 15-101; Ord. No. 2004-002, 12-7-2004; Ord. No. 2006-002, 2-1-2006; Ord. No. 2007-004, 12-4-2007) Sec. 34-65. - Solid waste assessment. There shall be a solid waste assessment imposed on all privately owned, single-family residential properties and camper lots located in the county to recover the costs associated with solid waste services provided by the county solid waste authority. There are eight tax districts in the county: Seven corresponding to the seven municipalities of the county and one for the unincorporated area of the county. The solid waste assessment will vary by tax district, based on the level of solid waste services offered by the specific governing body of the tax district and the county board of commissioners. The solid waste assessment will be collected as part of the annual county tax billing process in the same manner as prescribed for collection of said tax bill. (Code 1987, § 15-102; Ord. No. 2004-002, 12-7-2004; Ord. No. 2006-002, 2-1-2006; Ord. No. 2014-003, 3-4-2014) Sec. 34-66. - Solid waste assessment collection. (a) The solid waste assessment will be collected as follows: Individual, single-family, and private residential units in the county will be billed under the following tax districts at the rates as cited in section 34-71:
(b) Individual single-family, private residential properties will be billed as part of their annual property tax bill for the annual solid waste assessment. The annual solid waste assessment is not a tax, it is an assessment. As such the assessment is not based upon the taxable value of the residence but is an annual fee imposed equally on each specified property within the specific tax district. (c) The solid waste assessment for camper lots will be billed annually based on occupancy of the lot as of January of the calendar year for which the solid waste assessment covers, regardless of tax district. (1) The county tax commissioner will include the solid waste assessment with the property tax bill of all private, residential properties located in each county tax district. The tax commissioner will maintain a solid waste assessment billing register. Sixty days after the due date for the solid waste assessment, the tax commissioner will send a delinquency notice to each residential property owner who has not paid their correct solid waste billing. This notice will advise payment is due within 30 days or the delinquent account will be sent to the magistrate court for collection. Upon expiration of the 30-day delinquency notice time period, the tax commissioner will transmit a copy of the delinquent solid waste assessment billing register to the county board of commissioners for collection effort. (2) Upon receipt of the delinquent solid waste assessment billing register, the board of commissioners will prepare all necessary documentation for processing collection through the magistrate's court for collection of the delinquent solid waste assessment fees. (3) Delinquent solid waste assessment fees, as recorded on the delinquent register shall be deemed past due and delinquent, and will be charged a late fee equal to one percent, compounded monthly. (Code 1987, § 15-103; Ord. No. 2004-002, 12-7-2004; Ord. No. 2006-002, 2-1-2006; Ord. No. 2007-004, 12-4-2007; Ord. No. 2014-003, 3-4-2014) Sec. 34-67. - Credit for private residential collection/disposal services. Private, single-family residential property owners who have contracted with a licensed (EPD permitted) contractor for polycart service of household garbage may, upon proof of annual contract with the service provider, request reduction of their solid waste assessment by the household waste component cost of the solid waste assessment. If such private service has been for less than the billing year, the solid waste assessment will be reduced proportionately. (Code 1987, § 15-104; Ord. No. 2004-002, 12-7-2004) Sec. 34-68. - Determination of private residential properties for annual solid waste assessment billings; exclusions. (a) Units to be billed. Annually, the county board of commissioners, through the office of the county tax assessor, will determine the number of private residential units, by tax district, to be billed for the residential solid waste assessment. (b) Exclusions. (1) Commercial dwelling properties. Specifically excluded from this residential solid waste assessment are rental properties such as apartments, townhouses and mobile home or trailer parks. These residential properties are considered commercial enterprises and must provide full solid waste services for the individual residents of these complexes as detailed elsewhere in these ordinances. Residents of these rental properties are prohibited for using rural residential waste disposal facilities or commercial/business waste disposal containers provided by businesses other than containers provided by the owner of the rental property specified in this section. Fines for violation of this provision of the ordinance are detailed in section 34-70. (2) Low income senior citizens. Senior citizens classified on the county tax assessor's tax base as S-4, tax exempt, who earn $25,000.00 or less per annum, who are the sole source of income for the specific residential property, and who submit verifiable supporting documentation to the tax assessor's office by March 1 each calendar year, will be exempt from payment of the solid waste assessment for the next solid waste billing cycle. (Code 1987, § 15-105; Ord. No. 2004-002, 12-7-2004; Ord. No. 2007-004, 12-4-2007) Sec. 34-69. - Solid waste tipping fees. (a) There shall be a solid waste tipping fee imposed to recover the costs of siting, engineering, construction, operation, landfill closure and post-closure maintenance and monitoring, haul and disposal of the waste stream, and operation of the county solid waste transfer station. This solid waste tipping fee will be imposed on all public sector, private sector and commercial customers using the county transfer station (disposal facility). (b) The solid waste tipping fee imposed upon all users of the county transfer station (disposal facility) shall be in accord with the fee as cited in section 34-71. (c) The solid waste tipping fee as cited in section 34-71 for municipalities is established as Level 1, Level 2, and Level 3. These fee levels are based on the respective community's past commitment to the county solid waste authority. The following details the tipping fee charges for respective county municipalities: (1) Level 1: Hinesville, Flemington and Walthourville. (2) Level 2: Allenhurst, Gumbranch and Riceboro. (3) Level 3: Midway. (d) The exact transactional dollar amount of each solid waste tipping fee billing shall be determined at the solid waste transfer station through a measurement system using either weight, volume, or count, depending upon the type of solid waste being delivered to the facility, in accord with the solid waste tipping fees as cited in section 34-71. (e) Payment of the transacted solid waste tipping fee will be cash, check or charge for prearranged customer accounts. (f) Invoices shall be sent monthly by the county solid waste department to all solid waste tipping fee account holders, and shall be deemed past due and delinquent 30 days after receipt of said invoices. A late charge of 1.5 percent, compounded monthly, will be assessed against all delinquent amounts. (Code 1987, § 15-106; Ord. No. 2004-002, 12-7-2004; Ord. No. 2006-002, 2-1-2006) Sec. 34-70. - Violations. (a) Anyone who has not paid the county solid waste assessment fee to the county shall be prohibited from using the county solid waste collection and disposal facilities or any other associated county-operated or provided solid waste facility. (b) No one shall dispose of solid waste on private or public lands, nor within proper containers provided for the specific type of solid waste unless properly permitted to do so by the environmental protection division of the state department of natural resources. (c) No business or commercial enterprises shall use any county collection facilities unless specifically authorized. These facilities are solely for the use of residential property owners paying the solid waste assessment fee. (d) Any person violating any provision of this article shall be subject to a fine not to exceed those presented in section 34-105 or imprisonment for 60 days, or both. Further, it shall be considered a separate violation for each day the violation continues. Jurisdiction shall be in the magistrate court of the county and the procedure for enforcement of such shall be as provided in O.C.G.A. (Code 1987, § 15-107; Ord. No. 2004-002, 12-7-2004; Ord. No. 2006-002, 2-1-2006) Sec. 34-71. - Solid waste fees. In accordance with the adoption of the Liberty County Solid Waste Use Fee Ordinance, the solid waste assessment fee and solid waste tipping fee shall be in amounts as established by the board of commissioners from time to time. (Code 1987, § 15-108; Ord. No. 2004-002, 12-7-2004; Ord. No. 2006-002, 2-1-2006; Ord. No. 2007-004, 12-4-2007) Secs. 34-72—34-100. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - REGULATIONS FOR USE OF SERVICES AND FACILITIES
Sec. 34-101. - General use of facilities. Liberty County has established solid waste management services and facilities for authorized use by the residents, municipalities, and commercial and business establishments located in the jurisdictional boundaries of the county. This article details the authorized use of these specific facilities, sets forth user fees for specific facilities and establishes penalties for unauthorized use of said facilities. (Code 1987, § 15-201; Ord. No. 2006-001, 2-1-2006) Sec. 34-102. - Facilities description, service fees and authorized users. (a) Transfer station. This facility accepts conforming nonhazardous solid waste from collection sources such as jurisdictional municipal solid waste collection services (public and privately owned), county-operated solid waste collection services (rural and commercial clients), jurisdictional commercial and business (contract and cash) customers and nonjurisdictional private residential and nonjurisdictional commercial and business clients. All solid waste processed into the transfer station is charged a published disposal fee based on the customer and the solid waste material. Disposal fees are established by the county board of commissioners (see section 34-71) and are periodically adjusted. The current fee schedule is available through the county solid waste authority, at the transfer station. (b) Convenience centers. These facilities, located throughout the unincorporated area of the county, provide interim solid waste disposal/collection points for the unincorporated residents and municipal residents of Allenhurst, Flemington, Gumbranch, Midway, Riceboro and Walthourville. (This excludes Hinesville residents who have full range solid waste collection provided by the city and thus are not assessed for associated operational/disposal costs.) These convenience centers are for use by single-family residential property owners of the unincorporated area and municipalities described above. Operational costs for these facilities are recouped through the county solid waste assessment. Use by unauthorized commercial and business or nonjurisdictional parties is prohibited. Typically, each center includes one household waste compactor with a 38- to 40-cubic-yard enclosed receiving container and two 40-cubic-yard open top containers for disposal of yard waste, scrap metal and appliances (white goods) and bulky waste (brown goods). Additionally, each center provides facilities for acceptance of recyclable items. Service fees (annual residential solid waste assessment) for authorized customers are established by the county board of commissioners (see section 34-71) and are periodically adjusted. A listing of these fees is available, through the county solid waste authority, at the commissioner's office or at the county solid waste authority transfer station. (c) Rural dumpster sites. The county operates several rural dumpster sites in the unincorporated area of the county. Until these sites are closed, their use is restricted to those jurisdictional residents who pay for their operation through the annual residential solid waste assessment. Use by non-jurisdictional parties and/or commercial or business enterprises is strictly prohibited. (d) Recycling facilities. Six additional recycling facilities are located in the municipal boundaries of Hinesville (four locations), Walthourville (one facility) and Riceboro (one facility). These facilities, in addition to those co-located at each convenience center, are operated by the county solid waste authority for the sole use of county residents. No business or commercial use is authorized. The disposal of any type of nonconforming waste is unauthorized at these facilities. Recyclable items are to be placed in the appropriate bins or containers. Operational costs of these facilities are recouped through the annual residential solid waste assessment. (Code 1987, § 15-202; Ord. No. 2006-001, 2-1-2006) Sec. 34-103. - User fees. User fees have been established by the county board of commissioners for each of the facilities described above and are detailed in article II of this chapter. These fees are periodically adjusted by the board of commissioners. Current approved fee schedules are available at the commissioner's office or at the county solid waste authority transfer station. (Code 1987, § 15-202.1; Ord. No. 2006-001, 2-1-2006) Sec. 34-104. - Unauthorized use of convenience centers and recycling facilities. (a) Generally. The cost to operate the county convenience centers, rural dumpster sites and recycling facilities is funded by the annual residential solid waste assessment. Use of these facilities is strictly reserved for residents of the county who pay for their operation through the annual assessment. Unauthorized users will be cited and include those who plan to use (are physically located at a site) or have used a facility to discard solid waste or recyclables and persons who are scavenging or have scavenged items from the solid waste collection containers or recycling facilities. Unauthorized users will be cited and will be subject to court fees, fines and disposal costs as determined by the county magistrate court, the table of offenses, fines and disposal charges (see section 34-105) and the county solid waste authority. (b) Proof of authorization. The prima facie evidence of unauthorized use is the user's vehicle license plate. Out-of-county plates suggest the user is unauthorized. However, the out-of-county user is authorized to use the facility if they have received and paid the current annual residential solid waste assessment. A current paid receipt for the solid waste assessment supported by a second form of personal identification validates the authorized facility use by such residents. Officers of the county charged with validating solid waste facility users are to explain the reasons for verifying the user's residency; advise the out-of-county user to carry a copy of the paid solid waste assessment receipt; take the users name, home address and telephone number and license plate number and allow use of the facility. The name, address, license plate number and phone number will be transmitted to the litter control deputy for validation of authorized use. Fraudulent cases will be cited for unauthorized use through magistrate court. (c) Identification. Unauthorized users will be identified as follows: (1) Observation by the county litter control deputy or other solid waste authority employee. Observed use includes the physical act of waste disposal or being at a site with the intent to use the facility for waste disposal; or being on site to scavenge; being found in the act of scavenging; or found with scavenged material in their possession. (2) Reporting of apparent unauthorized use by the general public under the silent witness program or by calling the offices of the county commission or the solid waste authority. In such cases, prima facie evidence is being on site using a vehicle with an out-of-county license plate or operation of a vehicle with affixed business logo operated by the potential offender who has or plans to dispose of waste typical of the business, and, if available, a description of the individual and the vehicle, the time and facility being used, and the type of waste being disposed of or scavenged. Additional evidence of unauthorized use is identifiable discards of solid waste (letters, bank receipts, credit card slips, magazines with address labels, shipping containers with ship-to addresses, business papers, etc.). Reports of this type will be accepted telephonically, in writing or verbally. (3) Apprehension by an officer of the law. In this case, the apprehending officer will issue a citation to the offending party. No warnings will be given. (4) After-the-fact clean-up of materials disposed of at any of the county facilities or materials discarded elsewhere in the county (private or publicly owned lands). In such cases, prima facie evidence will be any item recovered from the discards which bears a name, address or other form of personal identification which would indicate the last ownership of the improperly discarded items. (d) Citation. Citations for unauthorized use of a county solid waste collection/disposal/recycling facility, unless issued by an officer of the law other than the county litter control deputy, will be written by the county litter control deputy and prosecuted through the county magistrate court. No warning will be issued since all facilities have been signed advising that unauthorized use is prohibited. (e) Payment of fines and disposal charges. The county magistrate court will prosecute each case. The county solid waste authority will provide the court with calculated weight tickets detailing the associated pull fees, disposal charges and clean-up costs as appropriate for each citation. These costs are to be added to the fines presented in the tables of offenses, fines and disposal charges shown below. Upon payment to the court, the applicable fines and disposal charges will to turned over to the county solid waste authority through the office of the Clerk of the Superior Court. (Code 1987, § 15-203; Ord. No. 2006-001, 2-1-2006) _____ Sec. 34-105. - Tables of offenses, fines and disposal charges. (a) Offenses, fines and charges regarding the use of county convenience centers are found in Table 34-105A as follows: TABLE 34-105A. OFFENSES, FINES AND DISPOSAL CHARGES UNAUTHORIZED USE OF COUNTY CONVENIENCE CENTERS
(b) Offenses, fines and charges regarding the use of county dumpster sites are found in Table 34-105B as follows: TABLE 34-105B. OFFENSES, FINES AND DISPOSAL CHARGES UNAUTHORIZED USE OF COUNTY DUMPSTER SITES
(c) Offenses, fines and charges regarding the use of county recycling facilities are found in Table 34-105C as follows: TABLE 34-105C. OFFENSES, FINES AND DISPOSAL CHARGES UNAUTHORIZED USE OF COUNTY RECYCLING FACILITIES
(d) Offenses, fines and charges regarding the scavenging of any county facility are found in Table 34-105D as follows: TABLE 34-105D. OFFENSES, FINES AND DISPOSAL CHARGES SCAVENGING (ANY FACILITY) WITHIN COUNTY
(Code 1987, § 15-204; Ord. No. 2006-001, 2-1-2006)

div.head: Chapter 36 - STREETS AND SIDEWALKS[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Authority of county to construct and maintain roads, including curbs, sidewalks, street lights and devices to control the flow of traffic, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, ¶ III(a)(4); damaging public property, O.C.G.A. § 16-7-25; governmental authorization for construction or maintenance of any private road unlawful, O.C.G.A. § 32-1-8; state, county and municipal road systems, O.C.G.A. § 32-4-1 et seq.; county road systems, O.C.G.A. § 32-4-40 et seq.; regulation of maintenance and use of public roads generally, O.C.G.A. § 32-6-1 et seq.; grants for construction and maintenance of county roads, O.C.G.A. § 36-17-20 et seq.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 36-1. - Road naming system established. There is hereby established a uniform system for the naming of all roads, streets and public ways in the unincorporated areas of the county. (Code 1987, § 15.5-1; Ord. No. 2010-009, § I, 9-7-2010) Sec. 36-2. - Road names. (a) The board of commissioners shall establish and assign names for all streets, roads and public ways in the unincorporated areas of the county. (b) Unless otherwise determined appropriate by the board of commissioners, no new road name assigned by the board of commissioners shall be a duplicate of or be similar to (either phonetically or by spelling) any existing street name in the unincorporated areas of the county. (c) Existing duplicate or similar road names shall be changed only as necessary to ensure the effectiveness and efficiency of the enhanced 911 system in the county, as determined in the judgment of the board of commissioners. (d) Historical names shall be the prime consideration in the assignment of road names, but shall not be the only or determinative consideration. (e) Unless otherwise determined appropriate by the board of commissioners, as many segmental roads as practical shall be identified as being a continuous road so as to reduce unnecessary road identifying names and numbers. (f) The county paved roads and historical roads, whether paved or unpaved, shall be named, and as funds are available the names and county road numbers shall be posted. Road naming within subdivisions shall comply with the county subdivision regulations and in addition be approved by the county 911 division prior to the final subdivision plat being approved and recorded in the office of the clerk of superior court of the county. (g) In the event there is a dispute as to the proper name of an existing road or a dispute as to whether an existing road has been previously officially named, the board of commissioners, in its absolute discretion, shall assign a name to the road under the same procedure for the naming of a new road. The decision by the board of commissioners as to the name assigned to such road shall be final and conclusive. (Code 1987, § 15.5-2; Ord. No. 2010-009, § I, 9-7-2010) Sec. 36-3. - Petition to change road name. (a) Upon receipt of a petition in the form and format as specified by the board of commissioners seeking a change of name of an existing named road, the board of commissioners shall take under consideration, but be under no compulsion to grant, said request; provided that any such petition shall contain the signatures of the owners or their authorized representatives (as specified below) of not less than 60 percent of the parcels of property abutting said public road. At its discretion, the board of commissioners may, but shall not be required, to hold a public hearing prior to deciding the issue of the proposed name change. (b) For purposes of this section, the owner of the abutting property shall be deemed to be the person or entity returning the property for ad valorem taxes in the office of the county tax commissioner. (1) If the property is returned in the name of an estate or trust, the legal representative of the estate or trust must sign the petition. (2) If the property is returned in the name of a corporation or a limited liability company, an authorized corporate officer, member, or manager, as the case may be, must sign the petition on behalf of said legal entity. (3) If the property is returned in the name of a partnership, each partner must sign the petition unless the signing partner has written authorization to sign for all other partners. (4) The determination by the board of commissioners as to the authority of the person signing the petition and the number of parcels abutting the road shall be final and conclusive. (c) Absent exigent circumstances (as determined by the board of commissioners in its absolute discretion), no petition to change the name of an existing public roadway will be considered if: (1) The name of said roadway has been changed within the previous 120 months; or (2) If a petition to change the name of said roadway has been denied by the board of commissioners within the previous 120 months. (Code 1987, § 15.5-3; Ord. No. 2010-009, § I, 9-7-2010) Secs. 36-4—36-24. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - ROAD AND DITCH PROTECTION
Sec. 36-25. - General limits on heavy vehicles. Heavy laden vehicles shall not proceed routinely over the county's unimproved road system during periods of rain or inclement weather when clearly said travel causes or has caused excessive damage to the roadway such that road conditions for the passage of smaller and lighter passenger vehicles has been substantially hampered. (Code 1987, § 15.5-51; Ord. of 9-4-1990, § 1) Sec. 36-26. - Penalty for violations. Failure of any person to comply with any of the provisions of this article shall constitute a misdemeanor, and be punished according to section 1-8. (Code 1987, § 15.5-53; Ord. of 9-4-1990, § 3) Sec. 36-27. - Administration and enforcement. The magistrate court of the county shall have jurisdiction over violations of this article and all procedures for enforcement of this article shall be as provided in O.C.G.A. Title 15, Chapter 10, Article 4 (O.C.G.A. § 15-10-60 et seq.). Complaints of violations of any provision of this article shall be brought before the magistrate court on a citation issued by a designated representative of the county board of commissioners or the chief magistrate of the county and shall be prosecuted through the court. Violations of this article will be tried upon citation either with or without a prosecuting attorney as determined by the county board of commissioners. Service of citation shall be performed by the constable of the magistrate court of the county. Citations shall meet all of the requirements as specified in the O.C.G.A. § 15-10-63 as amended. (Code 1987, § 15.5-54; Ord. of 9-4-1990, § 4) Secs. 36-28—36-57. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - TIMBER OPERATIONS
Sec. 36-58. - Purpose and Intent. This article is intended to require notice of timber harvesting operations within the unincorporated areas of the county pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 12-6-24, and, in accordance with O.C.G.A. Title 32, provide regulations further governing use of public roads by persons engaged in said timber harvesting operations in order to assure the public safety and to protect the county roadways and environment. (Code 1987, § 15.5-61; Ord. No. 2010-003, § 15.1, 6-1-2010) Sec. 36-59. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: County administrator means the county administrator for the county, or his designee. Notice means the notice required to be given to the public works department by the timber harvester as provided herein. Person means any natural person, firm, corporation, limited liability company, partnership, or other legal entity of whatever form. Public works department means the county public works department. Public works director means the director of the county public works department. Surety bond means a valid surety bond, executed by a surety corporation authorized to transact business in the state, protecting the county against any damage caused by such person or firm in an amount specified by the governing authority of the county not exceeding $5,000.00 or, at the option of the timber harvester, a valid irrevocable letter of credit issued by a bank or savings and loan association, as defined in O.C.G.A. § 7-1-4, in the amount of and in lieu of such bond. Any such surety bond or letter of credit shall be in the form prescribed by or acceptable to the county administrator and shall be for the calendar year in which delivered. Timber means softwood or hardwood trees harvested for commercial purposes. Timber harvester means any person harvesting standing timber in any unincorporated area of the county for delivery as pulpwood, logs, poles, posts, or wood chips to any wood yard or processing plant located inside or outside the state. (Code 1987, § 15.5-62; Ord. No. 2010-003, § 15.2, 6-1-2010) Sec. 36-60. - Notice required. (a) Written notice shall be required of any timber harvester harvesting timber in the unincorporated areas of the county for each separate tract to be harvested. Said written notice shall be: (1) Delivered to the public works department prior to entering onto the subject tract, if possible, but in no event later than 24 hours after entering onto said tract; and (2) In such form and containing such information as set forth in O.C.G.A. § 12-6-24(b)(1). (b) Notice shall be effective only as to the tract described therein upon receipt by the public works department (as confirmed by written acknowledgment from said public works department to the timber harvester) and compliance with all other applicable requirements of this article. Such notice may be given in person, by transmission of an electronic record via telefacsimile, e-mail, or such other means as approved by the governing authority of the county, or by mail. (c) Prior to and at all times during any timber harvesting operations subject to this article, the timber harvester shall additionally ensure that the requisite notice is continuously posted and displayed in good condition and in a conspicuous location on each tract of land identified in said notice. For purposes of this section, the notice shall be deemed posted in a "conspicuous location" if clearly visible and located in the immediate vicinity where the entrance road or trail providing vehicular access to the subject tract meets the nearest public right-of-way. (Code 1987, § 15.5-63; Ord. No. 2010-003, § 15.3, 6-1-2010; Ord. No. 2013-001, § I, 5-7-2013; Ord. No. 2015-001, § I(1), 7-7-2015) Sec. 36-61. - Surety bond. (a) A surety bond shall not be required prior to notice becoming effective. However, following the giving of any notice, in the event that the public works director determines that any activities relating to the timber harvesting are being conducted in a manner that poses likelihood of damage to any public rights-of-way or danger to the public safety, the public works department shall be authorized to demand a surety bond from the timber harvester. The surety bond shall be delivered to the public works department within three business days following receipt of written demand for the same, unless within said time a written notice of appeal is received by the public works department contesting the requirement of the surety bond. In the event of such contest, the public works department shall, no later than five business days, schedule an administrative hearing in such matter before the county administrator, who shall deliver a decision within three business days of said hearing. The decision of the county administrator shall be conclusive and binding for all purposes. Following any contest as provided above, all timber harvesting authorized pursuant to the applicable notice shall be suspended until the surety bond, if any, is delivered to the public works department as required by the county administrator. (b) The amount of the bond shall not exceed $5,000.00. The bond shall indemnify the county against any and all damage caused, as a result of the timber harvesting and related activities, to any county roads, rights-of-way, points of egress or other public property. The surety bond shall also indemnify the county for any costs incurred in the cleanup of waste or debris left on public property as a result of the timber harvesting. (c) Upon completion of any necessary repairs to public property and removal of all waste and debris, the county will release the timber harvester from the surety bond. (d) In no event shall the delivery of a surety bond limit the liability of any person engaged in timber harvesting and related activities for damages to public property or rights-of-way or for other personal injury or property damage. (e) No more than one surety bond shall be required at any one time from a timber harvester hereunder regardless of the number of tracts harvested in the unincorporated areas of the county so long as said surety bond remains in effect; provided that a valid replacement surety bond must be obtained and delivered to the public works department no later than the close of business on the fifth business day following the day that the county files a claim to recover damages against the then-existing surety bond. Upon filing such claim, the public works department or other designee of the county shall immediately provide notice thereof, including the date such claim was filed, to the person causing the damage. Such notice may be given in person, by transmission of an electronic record via telefacsimile, or by e-mail. For purposes of this section, any such surety bond shall be valid only for the calendar year in which delivered. (Code 1987, § 15.5-64; Ord. No. 2010-003, § 15.4, 6-1-2010; Ord. No. 2015-001, § I(2), 7-7-2015) Sec. 36-62. - Culverts. Prior to commencing timber harvesting operations, the public works director shall inspect the point of access to the public road from the tract described in the notice in order to determine its suitability. If a culvert is required at the point of access, it shall be promptly installed by the timber harvester as directed by the public works director. (Code 1987, § 15.5-65; Ord. No. 2010-003, § 15.5, 6-1-2010) Sec. 36-63. - Signs. Prior to commencing any timber harvesting operations, the timber harvester shall post two signs in each direction from the point of access onto the involved public road. One sign at a distance of 1,000 feet from the point of access stating, "Warning: Logging Operations Ahead," and one sign at a distance of 500 feet stating, "Slow Truck Entering Highway." All signs shall be 36 inches by 36 inches, erected in a diamond shape, painted orange with black legend and posted at least three feet from the travel surface of the roadway. (Code 1987, § 15.5-66; Ord. No. 2010-003, § 15.6, 6-1-2010) Sec. 36-64. - Roadway safety. During the period of operations, the timber harvester shall comply with the following: (1) All harvesting operations shall be conducted on the tract identified in the notice and off public roads and rights-of-way. Logging and skidding of logs on public roads and rights-of-way are strictly prohibited. (2) Ditches constituting a part of the public drainage system or otherwise benefitting a public right-of-way shall be kept clear of all debris and residue at all times to permit proper drainage. (3) There shall be no blockage of public roads or rights-of-way at the access site, and all public roads and rights-of-way must remain open and kept free of debris and residue at all times. (4) No equipment, trucks, trailers, or other personal property shall be parked or located on any public road or right-of-way. (5) Mud shall not be carried onto paved public roads by logging vehicles. Where necessary, a temporary construction exit of gravel shall be maintained by the timber harvester to eliminate any hazard to traffic or unsightly conditions on the public right-of-way. (6) During periods of rain or inclement weather, logging vehicles shall not be operated over the unimproved public roads when such travel causes sufficient damage to the road system that the passage of smaller and lighter vehicles is hampered. (Code 1987, § 15.5-67; Ord. No. 2010-003, § 15.7, 6-1-2010) Sec. 36-65. - Enforcement. (a) Upon notice from the issuing authority, work on any project that is being done contrary to the provisions of this article shall be immediately stopped. Such notice shall be in writing and shall be given to the timber harvester and the owner of the subject property, and shall state the conditions under which work may resume. When an emergency exists, written notice shall not be required. (b) If the conditions are not brought into compliance within five business days of the notice, the public works department shall be authorized to accomplish the work (with costs thereof to be reimbursed by the timber harvester), and any violation of the provisions of this article shall be punished as for a misdemeanor. (Code 1987, § 15.5-68; Ord. No. 2010-003, § 15.8, 6-1-2010) Sec. 36-66. - Concluding operations. (a) The timber harvester shall give written notification to the public works director within 24 hours following completion of the timber harvesting operations. The public works director shall inspect all affected public property and public rights-of-way to assure that the same has not been damaged or has been restored to its original condition, including any shaping of ditches, grading or seeding as required. The timber harvester shall be notified in writing of any deficiencies and given 15 business days to correct said deficiencies. If not accomplished during that period, the public works department (or its designee) shall be authorized to complete the work at the cost of the timber harvester. (b) When the public works director determines that the road and access site are in a proper state of repair, the director shall provide a written release of liability to the timber harvester. (Code 1987, § 15.5-69; Ord. No. 2010-003, § 15.9, 6-1-2010; Ord. No. 2015-001, § I(3), 7-7-2015) Sec. 36-67. - Prosecution of violations. (a) Any person violating any of the provisions of this article shall be guilty of a misdemeanor prosecutable in the magistrate court of the county and punished according to the general penalties described in section 1-8. (b) The county code enforcement officer shall be authorized to issue citations in order to initiate such prosecution. (c) The imposition of any fine or other sentence pursuant to this section shall in no way limit the liability of any person for damage done to public property or public rights-of-way, and the county shall be authorized to additionally pursue recovery for any such damage by any and all means permitted by law or in equity, to include, without limitation, the filing of a suit for damages, or the seeking of injunctive relief to stop any such damage. (Code 1987, § 15.5-70; Ord. No. 2010-003, § 15.10, 6-1-2010) Sec. 36-68. - Timber harvesting notice. (a) Prior to initiating any timber harvesting activities in the county on or after the effective date of the ordinance from which this section derives, the timber harvesting contractor shall give written notification to the board of assessors of the county within 24 hours prior to commencing start-up activities (moving in of equipment or cutting of any trees). (1) The notice shall be in the following form: NOTIFICATION OF HARVESTING
(2) Upon completion of the harvesting of the timber identified in the above form, the timber harvesting contractor shall give oral notification in person or by telephone to the tax assessor's office that the harvesting activities at the above described location have been completed. (b) The penalty for failure to comply with the reporting requirements set out in subsection (a) of this section shall be a fine not to exceed $1,000.00 and/or 12 months' imprisonment in the county jail. (c) Citations for violation of this section shall be prosecuted in the magistrate court of the county. (Code 1987, § 15.5-71; Ord. No. 2010-003, 6-1-2010)

div.head: Chapter 38 - UTILITIES AND WATER RESOURCES[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Home rule powers of municipality to regulate sewage collection and disposal systems and water treatment systems, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, ¶ III(a)(6), (7); Georgia Water Quality Control Act, O.C.G.A. § 12-5-20 et seq.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 38-1. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: County administrator means the individual designated by the board of commissioners as [the] county administrator responsible for the general supervision of all county departments, including the county water system. Customer means every person who is responsible for contracting (expressly or implicitly) with the county in obtaining, having or using water through the water system. The term "customer" shall also include illicit users of the water or water system. Department director or director means the person designated by the county as director of the county water system. Easement means any acquired legal right for the specific use of land owned by others. Grant means any federal or state grant or loan made to the county in connection with the water system, and any bonds issued or other documents executed in connection therewith, and all requirements and conditions imposed upon the county by virtue of the same. Ordinance means this ordinance, consisting of articles I through IV, as the same may hereafter be supplemented, amended, expanded, or otherwise modified. User means any person who receives water from the county water system. Water system or county water system means those tanks, wells, structures, valves, meter boxes, backflow prevention devices, facilities, lines, pipes, equipment, and other improvements owned, in whole or in part, or operated by the county and used in the withdrawal, pumping, storage, testing, treatment, processing, distribution, and delivery of potable water to the public, as said water system presently exists or as it may hereafter be improved, expanded or modified. (Code 1987, § 13-1; Ord. No. 2013-007, § I, 12-3-2013) Sec. 38-2. - Purpose and administration. (a) Generally. This chapter regulates the connection to and use of the county water system. (b) Administration. Except as otherwise provided in this chapter or directed by the county administrator, the department director or his agent shall administer, implement and enforce the provisions of the chapter. (Code 1987, § 13-2; Ord. No. 2013-007, § I, 12-3-2013) Sec. 38-3. - Permit required; connection mandated; private irrigation wells. (a) No person shall make a connection to or obtain water services from the county water system without first obtaining a permit for the same from the department director or his designee as required by this chapter. (b) Subject to those exceptions and limitations set forth in O.C.G.A. § 36-60-17.1 and any other applicable state or federal law, the water distribution system of any building constructed after January 1, 2014, in which plumbing fixtures are installed shall be connected to the county water system, if water service from said system is available. Water service shall be deemed available if water service from the county water system is furnished within 200 feet of said building and that the provision of water services thereto is otherwise feasible, as determined by the county administrator; provided, however, that in no event shall this section obligate the county to expand the water system or otherwise extend service to any property not then currently served. Any expansion of the water system or other provision of water therefrom shall be undertaken at the sole and complete discretion of the county. (c) Customers shall receive water services exclusively from the water system and no other source without the written consent of the county administrator, except that private wells located on or serving the customer's property may be used for irrigation purposes (and for irrigation purposes only). (Code 1987, § 13-3; Ord. No. 2013-007, § I, 12-3-2013) Sec. 38-4. - Application for connection permit; no false representations. (a) The owner of the land upon which a water connection is desired, or the owner's authorized agent, shall make application on a form furnished by the county. The permit application shall be supplemented by the owner's drawings, plans, specifications or other such information which, in the judgment of the department director, is considered to be pertinent to the desired connection. (b) All costs and expenses incidental to connection to the water system shall be borne by the owner. The owner shall indemnify the county against any loss or damage to the county water system that may be directly or indirectly occasioned by the connection. (c) It shall be a violation of this chapter for any user to knowingly make any false statements, representations or certifications in any application, record, report, plan or other documentation filed, or required to be maintained, pursuant to this chapter. (Code 1987, § 13-4; Ord. No. 2013-007, § I, 12-3-2013) Sec. 38-5. - Feasibility of providing water service. Water service may be provided from the county water system only following: (1) Submission of a completed application, as well as all supporting documentation requested by the department director; (2) Compliance with the provisions of this chapter, including, without limitation, the payment of all required fees and charges; (3) Appropriate connection to the county water system and installation of a water meter as required by this chapter; and (4) Determination by the county administrator that the requested provision of water services is feasible and consistent with sound water system operation. The owner of the property requesting water service shall submit plans, drawings, surveys, and other information as requested by the department director to assist the department director in making his determination under this section. (Code 1987, § 13-5; Ord. No. 2013-007, § I, 12-3-2013) Sec. 38-6. - Meter installation; location of connection; compliance with codes. (a) The consumption of all water furnished by the county water system shall be measured by water meters approved by the department director; provided that the department director shall not issue a connection permit or authorize the installation of a water meter until the fees required by this chapter for such connection and metering have been paid. All water meters and related shutoff valves shall be and remain the property of the county. (b) The department director shall be authorized to make a determination of the number of meters that may be required for condominiums, apartment buildings, apartment complexes or townhouses, shopping centers, mobile home parks, and other multifamily and multi-unit properties; provided, however, that sub-metering for all such properties shall be required to the extent practicable, as determined by the department director, and as may otherwise be mandated by applicable law. The owner of any such multifamily or multi-unit property shall submit plans, drawings, surveys, and other information as requested by the department director to assist the department director in making his determination under this section. (c) All connections to the county water system shall be made, and all water meters shall be installed, at such location as may be determined by the department director or his designee. Without limiting the foregoing, and absent the written authorization of the department director: (1) All water meters shall be installed at an easily accessible location on or near the property line of the premises being served adjacent to the public right-of-way; and (2) Water meters shall not be installed behind enclosed fences, in paved driveways or in paved parking areas. (d) The size, materials of construction, and methods of construction of all pipes, lines, and other facilities connecting to the county water system shall conform to all applicable local, state, and federal chapters, statutes, regulations, codes, and laws, including, without limitation, all plumbing, building, environmental, safety, health, and technical codes. (Code 1987, § 13-5.1; Ord. No. 2013-007, § I, 12-3-2013) Sec. 38-7. - Restoration of disturbed public property. Any construction work relating to the county water system and conducted on the public right-of-way or any public property by anyone other than county personnel shall be conducted only with proper, written permission from the department director. All disturbed areas as a result of such construction shall be restored, at the sole cost of the person undertaking the work, to substantially the same condition as prior to the disturbance. The scheduling of such construction activities shall be as approved by the department director if such scheduling approval is determined to be in the public's best interest. Additionally, as a condition to any such construction work, the director shall be authorized to require such deposit, bond, indemnification, and other assurances as the director determines appropriate. (Code 1987, § 13-6; Ord. No. 2013-007, § I, 12-3-2013) Sec. 38-8. - Easements restrictions; no permanent construction near easements. (a) Permanent easements granted, obtained, or otherwise used by the county in connection with the water system are established so that inter alia the county may properly install, inspect, observe, measure, sample, repair, protect, maintain, replace, and operate said water system. It is essential that access to the easement not be obstructed. Although the property owner owns the underlying fee simple title to the land within the easement area subject to the easement rights, all construction, digging, grubbing, clearing, filling, or other earth moving or construction activities by the owner in the permanent easement area are prohibited without prior permission from the department director or his designee. Permanent structures shall not be permitted within the easement or easement setback as provided in subsection (b) of this section. In addition, upon demand by the county, nonstructural improvements within easement areas (e.g., walkways, landscaping, etc.) are subject to immediate removal at the owner's risk and sole cost. The county shall not be liable for repairing, maintaining, or replacing (or otherwise reimbursing any person for) any item or improvement within the easement area that is removed to access, protect, repair, operate, or maintain the water system. (b) No permanent structures shall be constructed within ten feet of the edge of a permanent water easement on front and rear setbacks, or within two feet on side setbacks. The department director may grant a variance, in writing, to this requirement, provided that it can be demonstrated to his reasonable satisfaction that such structure will not impede future installation, maintenance, replacement and other activities relating to the county water system within said easement. (Code 1987, § 13-7; Ord. No. 2013-007, § I, 12-3-2013) Sec. 38-9. - Capping and sealing of discontinued water connections. All water service connections for which service has been discontinued as a result of the demolition of the structure being served by the connection, or for any other reasons, shall be properly and permanently capped and sealed to prevent the escape of potable water as required by the department director. (Code 1987, § 13-8; Ord. No. 2013-007, § I, 12-3-2013) Sec. 38-10. - Damage or interference with system; unlawful diversion of service. (a) It shall be unlawful for any person intentionally and without authority to: (1) Damage, tamper with, alter, or destroy any meter, pipe, conduit, wire, line, or other part of the county water system; (2) Prevent a meter from properly registering the quantity of water supplied; (3) Divert or use (or cause to be used) water from the county water system without the required permit or payment of all scheduled fees and charges; or (4) Otherwise interfere with the proper operation of the county water system. (b) Where there is no evidence to the contrary, the person performing any of the illegal acts described in this section and the person who with knowledge of such violation receives the benefit of such service without proper charge shall be presumed to be responsible for such acts of tampering or diversion. (c) Any person who violates subsection (a) of this section, upon citation and conviction of the violation in a court of competent jurisdiction, shall, in addition to civil and other penalties and remedies authorized in this chapter, be subject to imprisonment as provided in section 1-8. Where any offense or violation continues from day to day, each day's continuance thereof shall be deemed a separate offense. (d) In addition to fines and other criminal and civil penalties and remedies authorized hereunder, any person convicted for violation of this section shall pay retribution to the county for any damage to its equipment at current costs for labor and materials necessary to reestablish service and otherwise repair and replace damage portions of the county water system. (e) Any person negligently damaging or destroying any portion of the county water system shall also be liable for the full repair and replacement cost, as the case may be, of said damaged or destroyed components. (Code 1987, § 13-9; Ord. No. 2013-007, § I, 12-3-2013) Sec. 38-11. - Connection to private water system prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any person to physically interconnect a private well or other private water supply with the county water system, whether separated by shutoff values, backflow preventers, or any other device, and irrespective of the quality or characteristics of water in the private supply system. (Code 1987, § 13-10; Ord. No. 2013-007, § I, 12-3-2013) Sec. 38-12. - Continuity and quality of service; sovereign immunity preserved. (a) The county shall make every reasonable effort to provide continuous service and potable water. The county does not warrant that system malfunctions or deficiencies will not result in service interruptions or pressure changes, nor does it guarantee that water quality will not vary, nor does it guarantee that it will be directly suitable for special commercial or industrial processes. The county assumes no liability for damages caused by varying pressure, interrupted service or water quality changes. (b) The county reserves the right to shut off or diminish flow in system mains due to repairs, maintenance, emergencies, or water shortage. The department director shall endeavor to give public notice in the event of water shortage or prolonged routine maintenance interruptions of service. Notice is not required for emergency diversions of water or emergency repairs. (c) Under no circumstances will the county or any employee, contractor, or official thereof be liable for any damage, accident, or loss of any kind caused by or resulting from the discontinuance, suspension, or other unavailability of water services or its quality. (d) Neither this chapter nor any contract entered into or implied with respect to the county water system shall in any way waive or otherwise impair the county's sovereign immunity from suit or the official immunity of its employees and officers, and no services provided or actions taken by the county or its employees, officers, or contractors now or hereafter (or which any such person fails to take) with respect to this chapter and the county water system shall be deemed to so waive or impair the county's sovereign immunity or its employees or officers official immunity, and neither the county nor its officers or employees shall in any event be estopped from asserting their respective sovereign or official immunity to the fullest extent granted by the constitution and laws of the state. (Code 1987, § 13-11; Ord. No. 2013-007, § I, 12-3-2013) Sec. 38-13. - Supplemental ordinance. The requirements and other provisions of this chapter are supplemental to any and all other applicable local, state, and federal laws, ordinances, statutes, and regulations, and shall not preclude their application and enforcement. (Code 1987, § 13-12; Ord. No. 2013-007, § I, 12-3-2013) Sec. 38-14. - Additional regulations.
