The department director, with the consent of the county administrator, is authorized to adopt and implement such additional written regulations and policies as deemed necessary or desirable to better ensure the proper and efficient operation of the county of water system. (Code 1987, § 13-13; Ord. No. 2013-007, § I, 12-3-2013) Secs. 38-15—38-31. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - FEES AND CHARGES
Sec. 38-32. - Service charges and fees generally. (a) Purpose. It is the purpose of this article to establish a fee mechanism whereby the users of the county water services are charged for those services in an amount established by the county as being necessary to properly maintain, repair, replace, operate, and expand, as the case may be, the water system in a sound, businesslike manner and to provide adequate financial support for the same. (b) Customer classifications. Without limiting the right of the county to further define and establish customer classifications and categories, the following customer categories are established: (1) Residential customer is the owner or occupant of an individual structure used primarily as a residence and assigned one water meter. (2) Nonresidential customer is: a. The owner or occupant of a structure with assigned water meter that is used for commercial or institutional purpose, not as residence; or b. The owner of a building containing two or more dwelling units served by a single water meter. (c) Water connection charge. There is hereby levied and assessed a service charge for making connections to the county water system, to also include the costs of all water meters, backflow prevention devices, and related items necessary for connection to the water system. All amounts charged for water connections pursuant to this chapter shall be assessed to the owners of the property being connected, and such charges shall be collected prior to the making of such connection unless other payment arrangements are approved in writing by the department director. Water connection assessments shall be as shown on the rate and fee schedule on file and available at the office of the board of commissioners and the office of the department director. (d) Water tap charge. There is hereby levied and assessed a tap charge for all connections to the county water system, which shall be assessed to the owners of the property being served. All tap charges shall be collected prior to the making any connection to the water system unless other payment arrangements are approved in writing by the department director. Water tap charges shall be as shown on the rate and fee schedule on file and available at the office of the board of commissioners and the office of the department director. WATER USAGE RATES
WATER BASE RATES
WATER SERVICE CONNECTION FEES
* Provision of meter only, does not include meter box or connection to main. ADDITIONAL FEES
(e) Water service charge for usage. There are hereby levied and assessed rates, fees and/or charges for the service, maintenance, operation and amortization of the county water system. The actual rates, fees, and charges assessed by the county for water services provided shall be published in a separate rate or fee schedule. A copy of such rate or fee schedule shall be on file and available at the office of the board of commissioners and the office of the department director; provided, however, that the rates initially charged under this chapter are attached to the ordinance from which this subsection derives as exhibit "A" and by this reference approved by the said board of commissioners for all purposes. (f) Changes in rates. The rates, fees and charges assessed by the county in connection with the water system may be revised from time to time by affirmative action of the county board of commissioners as determined necessary by said board, in its sole and absolute discretion, to support the present and future financial needs of the county water system and to otherwise ensure for the water systems proper operation and compliance with all applicable laws and grant requirements; provided that a review of the regularly occurring water usage rates imposed pursuant to subsection (e) of this section shall be conducted no less than annually. (g) No free services. No free services will at any time be furnished from the county water system. (Code 1987, § 13-14; Ord. No. 2013-007, § I, 12-3-2013; Amend. of 9-2-2014, exh. A) Editor's note— The rates set forth in exhibit A to an amendment adopted September 2, 2014, have been included in this Code as part of this subsection at the direction of the county. Sec. 38-33. - Miscellaneous charges. In addition to any other fees and charges authorized or implied by this chapter, the following fees and charges shall also be authorized in connection with the county water system: (1) Delinquent billed accounts. All billed accounts are due and payable on the billing date. Billed accounts not paid within 30 days from the billing date are delinquent, and service may be disconnected by the county and a service charge added to the account. This delinquent service charge is applicable to each service call to discontinue service for delinquent accounts. The customer will be charged for the service call even if the service is not disconnected. (2) Service calls. All customer service calls shall be charged to the customer requesting the service in accordance with a fee schedule established by the county reflecting as closely as possible the actual cost to the county for rendering the services. Restoration of service will only be made during normal working hours. (3) Meter reinstallation due to nonpayment or failure to apply for service. A service charge to reinstall a meter shall be levied. (4) Meter replacement, damage. The county shall determine charges to be assessed against any person causing damage to any part of the water system. Without limiting the foregoing, a charge (inclusive of the service call) will be made to replace a meter which has been damaged or frozen, or has in any way been made inoperative. The damaged meter must be returned to the county. (5) Meter missing or stolen, replacement. A charge, based upon county cost, will be made to replace a missing or stolen meter. (6) Miscellaneous service calls. Service calls to uncover meters, raise meters where the yard has been backfilled or landscaped, or repair meter boxes or meter connections will be billed at county cost. (7) Returned checks. A processing fee will be charged for returned checks. If water service has been discontinued as a result of the returned check, the services in subsections (1) and (4) of this section will also apply. (8) Failure to apply for service. A fee will be charged to users who have not properly applied for service in their own name. A separate fee shall be charged for each trip made by the county in an effort to have the customer properly and successfully apply for service. Payment must be made by the applicant for all water services utilized subsequent to the former customer discontinuing service. (9) Water service deposits. Unless otherwise authorized in writing by the department director, a deposit is required on all accounts at the time water service is connected. This deposit shall be as defined within the rate schedule. The deposit shall be held on account for a period of not less than 24 months. After an account has established an excellent payment record for a consecutive 24-month period, the deposit shall be refunded. An excellent payment record shall mean there is no incident of delinquency, returned check, or a regular pattern of payment when past due, all as determined by the department director. The method of refund will be as a credit to the account or as a separate payment. If a deposit has been refunded and the account subsequently becomes delinquent, a deposit shall be required to be reestablished on the account, or arrangements approved by the department director made, prior to reestablishment of service. If an account is closed prior to a deposit refund, the deposit amount shall be applied to the final bill and a balance mailed to the customer as a credit refund. The county shall be under no obligation to deposit any service deposits in an interest-bearing account, and any interest earned on such monies while in the control of the county shall be the exclusive property of the county. (10) Unauthorized connection or usage. Fees will be charged for unauthorized water system connections and also for the unauthorized use of county water system services in an amount equal to the connection fees, usage fee, and other fees and charges that would have otherwise been charged for such connection and usage if the user had been authorized to make such connection and use such water services. (11) Other services. For any services not falling within the above definitions, the county may fix a charge on the basis of cost of labor and materials required. (12) When service charges payable; disconnection of service for failure to pay. The payment of the sum due shall be made monthly or at such other time as indicated by the county in accordance with a statement setting forth the amount due. Payment for services billed monthly and not made within 20 days from the due date shall be subject to a surcharge of ten percent of the delinquent account; provided that such surcharge shall in no event exceed the reasonable costs and expenses incurred by the county as a result of such delinquency. The amount of such surcharge shall be established, in writing, by the department director from time to time based on such costs incurred. The failure to make any monthly payments for 60 days after the original due date shall result in water service to the premises being discontinued, with or without notice. Failure to receive notice of the amount due shall in no way relieve the customer, or owner of the property served, from making payment as provided in this section. Should any customer, including the owner of the property, receiving water service fail to pay any non-reoccurring, monthly sum due pursuant to this section, the water service shall be discontinued until such sums, with penalties as provided in this chapter, are paid in full. The remedies specified herein shall be in addition to any other remedies and penalties authorized in this chapter. (13) Reconnection charge when water service interrupted for failure to pay service charge. Upon the failure of any customer receiving water service to make payment, the water service shall be interrupted, and in that event a reconnection charge shall be assessed and collected with all arrearage due before the water service will be restored; provided that the department director may authorize that the payment of such arrearage be made in installments, as determined by the department director to be reasonable and appropriate given the particular circumstances. (14) Oversized meter boxes. The customer shall additionally be responsible for the cost of any meter boxes or meter vaults which exceed the standard dimensions or specifications for water meter boxes prescribed by the department director, as well as any other costs and expenses incurred by the county in connection therewith. (Code 1987, § 13-15; Ord. No. 2013-007, § I, 12-3-2013) Sec. 38-34. - Persons liable for payment. All persons applying for water service shall be individually and personally liable for the payment of all fees and charges required under this chapter; provided, however, that, in the case of townhouses, apartment complexes, mobile home parks, or similar multi-unit properties located on the same plot of land, irrespective of whether units are located in the same building or not, the water bill shall be billed to the owner of the property served; but in the case of a condominium (as organized under O.C.G.A. § 44-3-70 et seq. or other provisions of law), the same shall be charged to the association, except in cases where each dwelling unit has its own water meter. (Code 1987, § 13-16; Ord. No. 2013-007, § I, 12-3-2013) Secs. 38-35—38-56. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - WATER CONSERVATION
Sec. 38-57. - Outdoor water use restrictions. All users of the county water system shall comply with those restrictions on outdoor water use set forth in section 14-19, as the same may be modified, supplemented, or restated from time to time. (Code 1987, § 13-17; Ord. No. 2013-007, § I, 12-3-2013) Secs. 38-58—38-87. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - BACKFLOW PREVENTION
Sec. 38-88. - Backflow prevention devices. Backflow prevention devices shall be required for all connections to the county water system as prescribed by regulations promulgated by the department director from time to time and maintained in said director's office and the office of the board of commissioners. (Code 1987, § 13-18; Ord. No. 2013-007, § I, 12-3-2013) Secs. 38-89—38-119. - Reserved. ARTICLE V. - ENFORCEMENT
Sec. 38-120. - Violations. Except as otherwise provided herein, the failure of any person to comply with any provision contained in this chapter shall subject such person to the penalties set forth herein. (Code 1987, § 13-19; Ord. No. 2013-007, § I, 12-3-2013) Sec. 38-121. - Consent orders. The department director may enter into consent orders, assurances of voluntary compliance or other documents establishing an agreement with any user responsible for noncompliance. Such documents will include a specific action to be taken by the user to correct the noncompliance within a specific time period specified by the document. (Code 1987, § 13-20; Ord. No. 2013-007, § I, 12-3-2013) Sec. 38-122. - Termination of service; lien created; interest on amounts due. (a) Termination generally. In order to enforce the operation of this chapter, the county shall have the power and authority to enter upon the property of any user who has violated any provision of this chapter to terminate the user's water service in any manner deemed necessary and appropriate by department director; provided that the county shall note terminate water service due to nonpayment of reoccurring usage fees until 60 days following the due date of such payment. In the event of such termination under this section, the county shall retain all rights to collect unpaid bills or amounts owed by the terminated user according to law or other provisions of this chapter. Such rates or charges, if not paid when due, shall constitute a lien upon the premises served, though no such lien shall be imposed against the premises to secure unpaid charges for water furnished unless the owner of such real property is the person who incurred the charges. Past due amounts shall bear interest at the same rate as would unpaid ad valorem taxes. (b) Restoration of service to rental property. When service is terminated to a rented premises, service may be restored to the premises upon request of a party, renter or owner, who is not personally liable for water service previously, who did not otherwise utilize waters services at the premises, and who was previously not delinquent in payment of the water bill at the premises. Additionally, water service shall not be refused to any single or multifamily residential property to which water has been furnished through the use of a separate water meter for each residential unit on application of the owner or new resident tenant of the premises because of the indebtedness of the prior owner, prior occupant, or prior lessee for water previously furnished. (Code 1987, § 13-21; Ord. No. 2013-007, § I, 12-3-2013) Sec. 38-123. - Civil liabilities and penalties. (a) Any person violating the provisions of this chapter shall be liable to the county for a maximum civil penalty under O.C.G.A. § 36-1-20 of $1,000.00 per violation per day. (b) The department director may recover reasonable attorneys' fees, court costs and other expenses associated with enforcement activities, including sampling and monitoring expenses and the cost of actual damages incurred by the county. (c) In determining the amount of civil liability, the court shall take into account all relevant circumstances, including, but not limited to, extent of harm caused by the violation, the magnitude and duration of the violation, any economic benefit gained through the user's violation, corrective actions by the user, the compliance history of the user and any other factor as justice requires. (d) Filing a suit for civil penalties shall not be a bar against, or a prerequisite for, taking any other action against a user. (Code 1987, § 13-22; Ord. No. 2013-007, § I, 12-3-2013) Sec. 38-124. - Injunctive relief. When the department director finds that a user has violated or continues to violate any provisions of this chapter, the department director may petition the appropriate superior court of jurisdiction through the county attorney for issuance of a temporary or permanent injunction, as appropriate, which restrains or compels the specific performance of the requirements imposed by this chapter. The department director may also seek such other action as is appropriate for legal and/or equitable relief. A petition for injunctive relief shall not be a bar against, or a prerequisite for, taking any other action against a user. (Code 1987, § 13-23; Ord. No. 2013-007, § I, 12-3-2013) Sec. 38-125. - Right to enter premises. (a) Duly authorized employees and representatives of the county and authorized representatives of applicable federal and state regulatory agencies bearing proper credentials and identification shall be allowed to enter all properties served by the county water system for the purpose of inspection, observation, measurement, sampling, monitoring, testing, and other necessary activities. The county may, but is not required to, provide the user with prior notice of the entry. (b) The rights of entry set forth in subsection (a) of this section shall be in addition to any and all rights granted to the county under any easements which it may hold. Additionally, and without limiting such other rights of the county, duly authorized employees and representatives of the county bearing proper credentials and identification shall be permitted, with or without notice, to enter all private properties through which the county holds an easement, whether by virtue of express grant or prescriptive right, for the purposes of maintaining, operating, repairing, or replacing the water system, including, but not limited to, inspection, observation, measurement, and sampling of any portion of the water system lying within such easement. (Code 1987, § 13-24; Ord. No. 2013-007, § I, 12-3-2013) Sec. 38-126. - Enforcement actions cumulative. Notwithstanding any provision herein to the contrary, all of the enforcement provisions set forth in this chapter are cumulative to any other enforcement procedures or remedies which may be available to the county either by this chapter or at law or in equity. (Code 1987, § 13-25; Ord. No. 2013-007, § I, 12-3-2013)

div.head: Chapter 40 - VEHICLES AND TRAFFIC[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Authority to provide devices to control the flow of traffic, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, ¶ III(a)(4); authority of county to regulate traffic in unincorporated areas, O.C.G.A. § 36-1-20; power of local authorities generally, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-371.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 40-1. - Vehicle storage facility—Definition; guidelines. (a) A vehicle storage facility shall be defined as a facility which is operated solely for the purpose of storing vehicles. Generally, this service will be available to insurance companies, finance companies, banks, repossession companies, individuals, governmental agencies and other related institutions. In no way should a vehicle storage facility be construed as being an automotive salvage facility or junkyard as defined under appendix A, zoning, art. III, general provisions, section 3.16, junkyards. (b) The following are minimum guidelines which must be adhered to in the operation of a vehicle storage facility: (1) Such facility shall only be located in an area zoned B-2. (2) Such facility shall be located on at least a 20,000-square foot storage site. (3) Dismantling of vehicles, in whole or in part, is prohibited. (4) Buying and/or selling or parts or vehicles in any manner is prohibited. (5) Repairs to vehicles on the site, other than emergency repairs which may be required to get a vehicle cranked and removed, are prohibited. (6) Wrecked vehicles or vehicles which are otherwise inoperable shall be removed from the site within 120 days from the initial date of storage (unless requested by a law enforcement officer to keep a vehicle at the site for a longer period). (7) Reasonable surveillance for security purposes shall be provided by the operator of the vehicle storage facility. (8) The facility shall be fenced with a heavy-duty wire fence not less than six feet in height with three strands of barbed wire around the top of said fence, said barbed wire to be angled outward of said fence. (9) Fire lanes of not less than 25 feet shall be maintained. (10) Vehicles shall not be stored in a double-decked fashion. (Code 1987, § 11-96; Res. of 5-3-1983(1), §§ 1, 2; Res. of 6-3-1986, §§ 1, 2) Sec. 40-2. - Same—Revocation of license for violation. Deviations from any of the guidelines listed above or for violation of any other applicable regulation relative to the operation or violation of any state or federal law governing such business shall authorize the governing authority to revoke the business license of said facility in addition to any other remedies provided by law in such cases. (Code 1987, § 11-97; Res. of 5-3-1983(1), § 3) Secs. 40-3—40-22. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - TOWING AND RECOVERY SERVICES
Sec. 40-23. - Applicability. This article is applicable to any towing and recovery service which hauls, moves or transfers motor vehicles, operable or inoperable, within the unincorporated areas of the county at the request or direction of the county, its employees or any law enforcement officer. Sec. 40-24. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Motor vehicle is as defined in the Official Code of Georgia Annotated. Towing and recovery service operation means any person who provides for hire by the general public by any means the hauling, moving or transferring from one place to another any damaged, disabled, inoperable, operable or impounded motor vehicle. (Code 1987, § 16-20; Ord. No. 2010-001, § I, 2-2-2010; Ord. No. 2010-002, § I, 4-6-2010) Sec. 40-25. - License required. Any towing and recovery service which hauls, moves or transfers motor vehicles, operable or inoperable, within the unincorporated areas of the county at the request or direction of the county, its employees or any law enforcement officer, shall first obtain a license to do so from the county licensing department or other department or officer designated for this purpose (the "licensing officer") before engaging in such business. Pursuant to compliance with regulations contained herein, one license shall be issued for each towing and recovery service which occupies a separate and distinct independent business location. (Code 1987, § 16-21; Ord. No. 2010-001, § I, 2-2-2010; Ord. No. 2010-002, § I, 4-6-2010; Ord. No. 2014-002, 10-7-2014) Sec. 40-26. - Application; regulatory fees. (a) Application for a license to conduct a towing and recovery service operation as required under this article shall contain the following additional information: (1) Trade names used during the previous five years by the applicant and each person signing the application along with the locations of prior establishments. (2) The names and addresses of the owners of such business. If such business is a corporation, the names and addresses of all persons owning stock in said corporation. (3) Such other information as may be prescribed from time to time on forms prepared by the licensing officer pursuant to this article. (b) Any person or other legal entity wishing to conduct two or more towing and recovery service operations under this article shall apply for and obtain a license to do so for each and every towing and recovery service operation so conducted, and shall otherwise ensure that each such operation independently satisfies all the requirements of this article. (c) All applications must be accompanied by: (1) Copies of the vehicle registration of each and every heavy-duty wrecker and light duty wrecker to be used in the towing and recovery service operation; (2) Evidence of insurance as prescribed in section 40-29; (3) Any and all other information and items as may be required by this article or the license application authorized herein; (4) Copy of current and valid business license issued by governmental authority within the county; (5) Copy of proof of registration/inspection with the Georgia Department of Public Safety; and (6) All fees specified in subsection (f) of this section. (d) The application, license, and other documents and papers necessary to the implementation and enforcement of this article shall be on such forms as may be prepared by the licensing officer and approved by the county administrator. No application shall be considered by the licensing officer until such application is complete and accompanied by all necessary documents, papers, and other evidence of eligibility as may be set forth or otherwise required by the application. All such applications shall be sworn to by the applicant if an individual, or by a partner if a partnership, or by a manager or member if a limited liability company, or by an officer or equivalent position if a corporation or other legal entity. (e) Licenses issued pursuant to this article shall be valid only for the calendar year in which they are issued. All licensees wishing to renew their license from the previous year shall make application for such license on or before December 31. Notwithstanding any terminology used in this article or any other provision herein to the contrary, the granting of a license for one year shall in no way vest any rights or privileges whatsoever to a licensee to any renewal or subsequent license, and such person must satisfy in full the requirements for such license established by ordinance at the time of such renewal. (f) Each applicant hereunder shall be required to pay a regulatory fee in connection with any application submitted (or license renewal). The regulatory fees levied and charged are set forth on a schedule R, a copy of which is on file in the county administrator's office and/or the office of the licensing officer. Regulatory fees are levied and assessed in addition to any business or occupational taxes assessed and levied under this Code of Ordinances. (Code 1987, § 16-22; Ord. No. 2010-001, § I, 2-2-2010; Ord. No. 2010-002, § I, 4-6-2010) Sec. 40-27. - Conditioned on compliance with article. The operating requirements set forth in this article shall apply to all towing and recovery service operations licensed in accordance with the provisions of this article and each operating requirement herein is a condition precedent to obtaining such a license and maintaining such license and the failure to abide by the requirements at all times shall be cause for suspension, revocation and/or denial of such license. (Code 1987, § 16-23; Ord. No. 2010-001, § I, 2-2-2010; Ord. No. 2010-002, § I, 4-6-2010) Sec. 40-28. - Availability at established rates; phone contact. All such towing and recovery service operations shall make available to the county on a 24-hour basis, every day of the year, said services when and as called upon at a price not more than the established maximum service fees provided hereinafter. In this connection, every towing and recovery service operator shall provide a phone number in its application which shall be used to contact said operator for all towing and recovery services hereunder. (Code 1987, § 16-24; Ord. No. 2010-001, § I, 2-2-2010; Ord. No. 2010-002, § I, 4-6-2010) Sec. 40-29. - Insurance. (a) Liability insurance. Prior to the issuance of the license required by this article and prior to the conduct of any such operations by said towing and recovery service, such towing and recovery service shall obtain and cause to be kept in force at all times during the term of any such license, liability insurance issued by a company or companies of sound and adequate financial responsibility of the following types and minimum amounts: Public liability insurance; bodily injury and property damage, $500,000.00 per occurrence, single limit coverage; garage keepers legal liability insurance with limits of $100,000.00 and on the hook cargo insurance (light duty wrecker: $50,000.00; heavy duty wrecker: $100,000.00). (b) Naming of county as certificate holder. Said insurance policy or policies shall name the county as a certificate holder and such policies of liability insurance shall not thereby cause the county to be deemed a partner or joint venture with the towing and recovery service operator in its business. (c) Workers' compensation insurance. Such towing and recovery service operator shall also carry workers' compensation insurance in the amounts and form required by the Workers' Compensation Act and insurance laws of the state and shall furnish proof of same to the licensing officer, prior to the granting of any license hereunder and from time to time upon request by said joint planning commission. (d) Copies of certificates. Copies of the certificates of all insurance coverage required of the towing and recovery service shall be filed with the licensing officer, and shall provide therein that the policies of insurance referred to in such certificates shall not be subject to cancellation by the insurer except after delivery of written notice by certified mail to the licensing officer at least 30 days prior to the effective date of any such cancellation. (e) Revocation of license for failure to provide. Should the service operator fail or refuse to obtain and keep in full force and effect the insurance required by this article, the license issued hereunder may be suspended or revoked as provided herein. (Code 1987, § 16-25; Ord. No. 2010-001, § I, 2-2-2010; Ord. No. 2010-002, § I, 4-6-2010) Sec. 40-30. - Storage facilities. Within the area of the county (including municipalities), the towing and recovery service operator shall provide or contract for an area for the storage of vehicles which have been moved, hauled or transferred by the towing and recovery service operator at the request of the county, its employees or any law enforcement officer. Towing and recovery service operators are permitted to share or utilize the facility of another operator so long as that facility complies with the requirements contained in this article. All impounded motor vehicles hauled or towed by such towing and recovery service shall be stored in said storage facility and an office shall be maintained at the storage area for the convenience of the public in retrieving their vehicles. This office shall be available to the public on an on-call basis 24 hours every day of the year; provided, however, that said office shall maintain regular business hours from 8:00 a.m. to 6:00 p.m. Monday through Friday. Such facility must be maintained properly, clean and presentable at all times and shall be subject to inspection by the county sheriff's department or its designee. Failure to properly maintain facilities shall be cause for revocation of the license granted hereunder; further, no impounded automobile hauled, moved, retrieved or transferred from one place to another by the towing and recovery service operator shall be stored at any place whatsoever other than a storage area which meets the following minimum requirements: (1) Such storage area shall meet all county zoning requirements and ordinances pertaining to vehicle storage. (2) The storage area and premises shall be kept in a clean and orderly condition. (3) There shall be ample space to store a minimum of 25 automobiles at the same time. The standard size automobile to be used for determining whether such storage facility meets the approval of this requirement is seven feet by 16 feet. (4) All other vehicles hauled by such towing and recovery services (those that are not impounded by the county) shall be stored in a storage facility that is either licensed as such by the City of Hinesville, the county, or any municipality within the county. (Code 1987, § 16-26; Ord. No. 2010-001, § I, 2-2-2010; Ord. No. 2010-002, § I, 4-6-2010; Ord. No. 2014-002, 10-7-2014; Ord. of 4-7-2015, § 16-26) Sec. 40-31. - Rendering service on call. Services are to be rendered immediately upon request from the county 911 central dispatcher. The towing and recovery service operator shall not respond to the scene of an accident unless called to the scene by the county 911 central dispatcher; provided, however, that this article recognizes the right of an individual who is the owner of any wrecked or impounded vehicle to select such person's own towing and recovery service company provided such person's state of sobriety or capacity is assured and provided that said vehicle is not blocking the roadway and is not otherwise dangerous to the traveling public. (Code 1987, § 16-27; Ord. No. 2010-001, § I, 2-2-2010; Ord. No. 2010-002, § I, 4-6-2010) Sec. 40-32. - Compliance with safety requirements; background check of applicant; disqualification for certain crimes. (a) The towing and recovery service operator shall comply with and conform to all federal, state and local laws and rules and regulations now in effect or as new ones become applicable, to include, but not by way of limitation, processing abandoned motor vehicles. (b) The towing and recovery service owners must submit to a background police and general records check for prior offenses or irregularities to determine suitability, reliability and financial stability in order to properly protect the public against abuse, neglect or malfeasance. No person who has been convicted of a felony or any crime involving moral turpitude shall be granted a license pursuant to the terms of this article. (Code 1987, § 16-28; Ord. No. 2010-001, § I, 2-2-2010; Ord. No. 2010-002, § I, 4-6-2010) Sec. 40-33. - Required vehicles. (a) Prior to the issuance of any license hereunder, the towing and recovery service operator must have and demonstrate the applicant's ownership of the following types of equipment: (1) One heavy-duty wrecker. A heavy-duty wrecker is defined as a wrecker with at least 32,000 pounds' minimum gross vehicle weight rating equipped with a 16- to 25-ton power take-off power winch, with dual rear wheels; or (2) Two light-duty wreckers. A light-duty wrecker is defined as a wrecker with at least 10,000 pounds' minimum gross vehicle weight rating equipped with 8,000-pound power take-off power winch, with dual rear wheels. One roll back or car carrier may be substituted for one light-duty wrecker. A light-duty car carrier is defined as a wrecker with at least 10,000 pounds' gross vehicle weight with dual rear wheels, and a power-driven winch with complete hydraulic wrecker system. (b) Recovery service operators shall be permitted to contract for the provision of heavy-duty vehicles so long as the contract provider meets all requirements of this article. However, calls for service will be distributed to the main service operator who must ensure that the required equipment arrives within timeframes required under section 40-39. (c) Each towing and recovery service operator licensed under this article shall be placed on the appropriate call list specified in section 40-39. (Code 1987, § 16-29; Ord. No. 2010-001, § I, 2-2-2010; Ord. No. 2010-002, § I, 4-6-2010; Ord. of 4-7-2015, § 16-29) Sec. 40-34. - Towing and recovery service items. Each wrecker provided hereunder shall be required to carry a full complement of service items such as fire extinguishers, chains, ropes, blocks, dollies, sports car bar, motorcycle bar, stoplights, flashers, floodlights, hand tools, lock-out tools, wrecking bars, brooms, and any other tools reasonably required for safe and effective lifting, extracting, righting and removal of a wrecked or disabled vehicle (or related debris) or other equipment from public thoroughfares. (Code 1987, § 16-30; Ord. No. 2010-001, § I, 2-2-2010; Ord. No. 2010-002, § I, 4-6-2010) Sec. 40-35. - Failure to provide required equipment; inspection of vehicles. If at any time after the granting of the license required by this article, the towing and recovery service operator fails to maintain the equipment required by this section such failure shall be cause for the suspension or revocation of said license. (Code 1987, § 16-31; Ord. No. 2010-001, § I, 2-2-2010; Ord. No. 2010-002, § I, 4-6-2010) Sec. 40-36. - Service fees. (a) The towing and recovery service operator will charge the public for all services rendered at rates not greater than those set forth herein as follows: (1) Light-duty wrecker: $90.00 maximum per hour and $22.50 every one-quarter hour thereafter. (2) Heavy-duty wrecker: $175.00 maximum per hour and $43.75 per one-quarter hour thereafter. (b) Such rates shall be conspicuously posted in the towing and recovery service operator's place of business for the attention and information of the general public and for claimants of vehicles under the towing and recovery service operator's care. All billings or statements of charges are to be itemized and will have clearly printed on the reverse side, the rates applicable pursuant to this section so that they may be verified by the claimant. (Code 1987, § 16-32; Ord. No. 2010-001, § I, 2-2-2010; Ord. No. 2010-002, § I, 4-6-2010) Sec. 40-37. - Telephone and radio communication. The towing and recovery service operator will provide, at no cost to the county, a designated telephone number and line to be used exclusively by the county 911 central dispatcher for the purpose of notifying a towing and recovery service operator whenever such towing and recovery service operator's services are needed. Paging services shall not be authorized. (Code 1987, § 16-33; Ord. No. 2010-001, § I, 2-2-2010; Ord. No. 2010-002, § I, 4-6-2010) Sec. 40-38. - Minimum number of drivers; driver information. The towing and recovery service operator must have available at all times at least one qualified towing and recovery operator with a valid driver's license issued by the State of Georgia, or, if the towing and recovery service operation maintains a wrecker having a GVW of 26,001 pounds or more, at least one qualified wrecker operator with a valid commercial driver's license (CDL). The towing and recovery service operator must submit a list of drivers' names, social security numbers, dates of birth, and drivers' license numbers to the joint planning commission, designated agent of the county for this purpose, prior to the issuance of any license and if from time to time towing and recovery servicer operators are deleted or added to the towing and recovery service operator's payroll, such operator must furnish an up-to-date list of such operators to the joint planning commission, the designated agent of the county. (Code 1987, § 16-34; Ord. No. 2010-001, § I, 2-2-2010; Ord. No. 2010-002, § I, 4-6-2010) Sec. 40-39. - Rotating operator list. (a) The licensing officer shall compile a listing of towing and recovery service operators licensed under this article that are qualified to accept calls for the purposes of hauling or storing vehicles as those terms are defined herein. Towing and recovery service operators shall be contacted for calls on a rotating basis in the order that they appear on said list; that is, the operator shall be selected which next succeeds the last operator called for towing and recovery services. Selections shall proceed in a like manner until the end of the list is reached, at which point, a towing and recovery service operator shall be selected from the top of the list, and so on, consecutively. The order of towing and recovery service operators on each list shall be as shown on the list maintained by the county 911 center as it exists as of such date or as otherwise directed by the county administrator. Thereafter, each list shall be regularly updated by the licensing officer, with any new licensees being added to the appropriate list in the order in which their application was approved. No towing and recovery service operator may be listed on any one list more than once, and may in no event use alternate legal entities or employ other strategies so as to effectively circumvent said limitation. When a towing and recovery service operator has failed or refused to respond as required herein, or has failed to reach a vehicle within the time prescribed herein, said operator shall be passed over on the applicable rotation list and shall be deemed to have responded for purposes of determining selection on the following call. The county 911 central dispatcher (or other authorized officer) shall call towing and recovery service operators in accordance with the applicable rotating list based on the instructions of the public safety officer or other responsible official at the scene. (b) Any wreckers called by the county 911 central dispatcher shall be required to reach the vehicle to be hauled within 45 minutes of said dispatcher's call, and after said 45-minute period said dispatcher shall be authorized to call the next towing and recovery service operator eligible for a call on the list maintained pursuant to subsection (a) of this section. The refusal or failure of any towing and recovery service operator to immediately answer any call shall be deemed a refusal to answer. The failure or refusal to answer a call, or the failure to reach a vehicle within the time prescribed, three or more times within any six-month period shall be grounds for suspension or revocation of the license issued hereunder. (Code 1987, § 16-35; Ord. No. 2010-001, § I, 2-2-2010; Ord. No. 2010-002, § I, 4-6-2010; Ord. of 4-7-2015, § 16-35) Sec. 40-40. - Display of license. All licenses issued under this article shall be posted conspicuously: (1) In the place of business of the towing and recovery service operator; and (2) In each and every heavy-duty wrecker and light-duty wrecker used by said operator in its towing and recovery services. (Code 1987, § 16-36; Ord. No. 2010-001, § I, 2-2-2010; Ord. No. 2010-002, § I, 4-6-2010) Sec. 40-41. - Denial, suspension or withdrawal of license. (a) A license or an application for a license under this article may be denied, suspended or revoked only for due cause as defined in subsection (c) of this section. A license may be denied or suspended by the licensing officer as set forth in this article; provided, however, that a license may be revoked only after a hearing before the governing authority of the county upon a prior written notice to the applicant or licensee of the time, place and purpose of such hearing and a statement of the reason why the license is to be revoked. Three days' notice shall be deemed reasonable, but shorter or longer periods of notice shall be authorized as the board of commissioners may deem the circumstances justify. Unless the circumstances otherwise justify, the hearing shall be generally held no later than 45 days after the fully completed application is filed with the licensing officer, or after the licensing officer has suspended a license. If a license is denied by the licensing officer under this article, the reasons for such denial shall be set forth in writing to the applicant. The applicant shall have 30 days following receipt of notice of denial to appeal the decision of the licensing officer to the governing authority, which shall review such application de novo at the next regular meeting of the governing authority following receipt of any such appeal, or, at the election of said governing authority, at a special meeting within 45 days following said appeal; provided, however, that any appeal received within ten business days prior to the next regular meeting of the governing authority shall be heard at the second regularly scheduled meeting of said governing authority following receipt of said appeal. If the governing authority affirms the decision of the licensing officer, then the license shall be denied. If the decision of the licensing officer is reversed, then the license shall be issued to the applicant. Alternatively, the governing authority may elect to issue the license subject to such reasonable conditions as the governing authority deems appropriate. (b) The licensing officer may suspend a license where there is evidence of due cause under subsection (c) of this section for revoking the license. Such action by the licensing officer shall be reported, in writing, to the governing authority. This action shall be reviewed at the next regular meeting of the governing authority, or, at the election of said governing authority, at a special meeting within 30 days following said suspension. If the governing authority affirms the decision of the licensing officer, then the license shall be permanently revoked. If the decision of the licensing officer is reversed, then the license shall be returned to the licensee immediately. Alternatively, the governing authority may elect to return the license to the licensee subject to such reasonable conditions as the governing authority deems appropriate. (c) A license or application therefor under this article may be denied, suspended or revoked if one or more of the following exists: (1) The applicant or licensee has failed to obtain any paper, permit, approval, or document required under this article. (2) The applicant or licensee has supplied false information to the licensing officer or the governing authority. (3) The applicant or licensee has violated any federal, state, or local statute, ordinance, regulation, rule, or law applicable to the towing and recovery services, to include, without limitation, any provision contained in this article. (4) Allowing any condition relating to the towing and recovery services that endangers public health or safety. (d) Unless otherwise determined by the board of commissioners following a hearing as provided herein, any licensee may petition for reinstatement of any license revoked hereunder no sooner than six months from the date of revocation. Such petition shall be submitted on forms provided by the county, and shall first be reviewed by the Liberty County 911 Board (or other person or body designated by the county administrator), who, following a hearing in the matter, shall make a recommendation regarding reinstatement to the board of commissioners. Said recommendation shall be nonbinding, and shall be decided by the board of commissioners following a subsequent hearing in matter. (Code 1987, § 16-37; Ord. No. 2010-001, § I, 2-2-2010; Ord. No. 2010-002, § I, 4-6-2010) Appendix A - ZONING[1] Footnotes: --- (1) --- Editor's note— Printed herein is the county zoning ordinance, Ordinance No. 2012-001, adopted March 15, 2012. Amendments are indicated by parenthetical history notes following amended provisions. The absence of a history note indicates that the provision remains unchanged from the original. Obvious misspellings and punctuation errors have been corrected without notation. Additions made for clarity such as consistent state statute citations and catchline modifications are indicated by brackets. Ordinance No. 2012-001 amended the prior county zoning ordinance in its entirety, which was adopted on July 23, 1975. State Law reference— Authority of municipality to adopt plans and exercise the power of zoning, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, ¶ IV; the Zoning Procedures Law, O.C.G.A. § 36-66-1 et seq.; local government zoning powers, O.C.G.A. § 36-66-2.
ARTICLE I. - INTRODUCTION AND ENACTMENT
1.1. - Title. These regulations shall be known and may be cited as the "Zoning Ordinance of Liberty County, Georgia." (Ord. No. 2012-001, 3-15-2012) 1.2. - Enactment. Whereas the board of commissioners of Liberty County has acted pursuant to the authority as amended by the regular 1973 session of the General Assembly of Georgia, the following ordinance to be known as the "Zoning Ordinance of Liberty County, Georgia" is hereby adopted and ordained effective the twenty-third day of July 1975. As part of this ordinance so enacted into law is the "Official Zoning Map of Liberty County," said map being identified by the inscription: "Zoning Map of Liberty County" adopted on the twenty-third day of July 1975; and signed by the clerk of the board of commissioners. (Ord. No. 2012-001, 3-15-2012) 1.3. - Purposes. The zoning regulations and districts as herein set forth are made in accordance with the comprehensive land use plan of Liberty County, with consideration for the character of the county, its various parts and structures, and in order to promote, protect and facilitate the public health, safety and welfare of the inhabitants of the county, and of the public generally. The danger and congestion in travel and transportation, loss of health, life or property or other dangers. The ordinance is also intended to support the following community development objectives: Appearance. To improve the appearance and utility of the land and structures in the county and to control the filling of floodplains, misuses of marshlands and streambanks, use of signs, and screening of junkyards and other areas of bad appearance. Education. To help maintain public and private school systems, capable of maximizing a student's potential, including large administrative districts with diversified educational opportunities. To better educate people of all ages, races, incomes, mental capabilities and physical handicaps. Transportation. To create an integrated transportation system, by using public transportation to its maximum effectiveness, and integrating it with private transportation, and to prepare and obtain acceptance of a continuing transportation system for the county, and particularly to assist low-income groups and elderly citizens in obtaining better transportation to jobs and shopping areas. Recreation and tourism. Provide sufficient recreation facilities, particularly at the community level, and promote tourism to the greatest extent possible. Pollution. Eliminate or reduce major sources of pollution. Flooding. To provide additional flood protection for critical areas, and to discharge development in floodprone areas that would be damaged by flooding. Housing. To provide an adequate supply of safe and sanitary housing in a decent environment for all income groups, regardless of race, color or background, including the rehabilitation of existing structures. Crime prevention. To reduce the incidence of crime to the extent possible. Economics. To increase the tax base by providing land for commercial and industrial growth where feasible, and minimize the conflict between industrial and commercial growth and residential or public development. Utilities. To promote the provision of public and private utilities. Land use and comprehensive plans. To use the zoning ordinance as a tool to help implement the land use and comprehensive plans. Health. To improve the health of the residents of the county by controlling pollution, separating new residences for adequate light, sun and air, and providing adequate treatment facilities at the lowest possible cost. Compliance. Except as hereinafter provided, no land, building, structure or premises shall hereafter be used, and no building or part thereof or other structure shall be located, erected, reconstructed, extended, enlarged, converted, altered or moved except in conformity with the regulations herein specified for the district in which it is located, and in conformity with all duly ordained ordinances, resolutions and subdivision regulations of the county. No yard space or minimum area required for a building or use shall be considered as any part of the yard space or minimum area for another building or use. (Ord. No. 2012-001, 3-15-2012) ARTICLE II. - DEFINITIONS
2.0. - Schedule. For the purpose of the administration and enforcement of this ordinance, and unless otherwise stated in this ordinance, the following words shall have a meaning as indicated herein: Words used in the present tense shall include the future tense; words used in the singular number shall include the plural number; words used in the plural number shall include the singular number; the word "shall" is mandatory, not directory. 2.1. Accessory building. A secondary residence, garage, or other building or structure subordinated to and not forming an integral part of the main or principal building on a lot or parcel but pertaining to the use of the main building. 2.2. Advertising signs. A surface whereon advertising material is set in public view, including reference to any use of premises whereon it is displayed or posted. 2.3. Alley. A narrow thoroughfare dedicated or used for public passageway up to twenty (20) feet in width, which usually abuts the rear of the premises, or upon which service entrances or buildings abut, and which is not generally used as a thoroughfare by both pedestrians and vehicles, which is not used for general traffic, and which is not otherwise officially designated as a street. A way which affords only a secondary means of access to abutting property. 2.4. Alterations. Any change in the arrangement of a building, including any work affecting the structural parts of a building; or an enlargement; or any change in wiring, plumbing, heating, or cooling system; and includes the words "to alter" and "alter". 2.5. Apartment building. A building which is used or intended to be used as a home or residence for more than two (2) families living in separate quarters. 2.6. Automotive sales and services. The sale or storage of new or used automobiles, including paint and body repair shops. 2.7. Billboard. A billboard is a free-standing sign, excluding off-premises directional signs as defined hereinafter, that exceeds the maximum sign face or sign structure area permitted by right on a property under the provisions of section 3.38.7. A billboard may be allowed individually as a principal use on a property under the conditions outlined in section 3.38.2 or 3.38.3. 2.8. Boathouse. A house or shed for sheltering one (1) or more boats. 2.9. Boundary of district. The centerline of a street or right-of-way or the centerline of an alleyway between the rear or side property lines, or, where no alley or passageway exists, the rear or side property lines of all lots bordering on any zoning district limits or any zoning district boundary shown on the maps adopted by section 4.2. 2.10. Buildable area. That portion of any lot which may be used or built upon in accordance with the regulations governing the given zoning district within which the particular lot is located, once the various front, side and rear yard requirements required for the district have been subtracted from the total lot area. 2.11. Building. A building is any structure having a roof entirely separated from any other structure by space or by walls, having no communicating doors or windows or any similar opening, and being erected for the purpose of providing support or shelter for persons, animals, things or property of any kind, and having a foundation to which it is anchored. 2.12. Building height. The height of a building with a gabled or hip roof shall be the vertical distance measured from the average elevation of the finished building site to the top of the roof of the uppermost story or to the deck line of a mansard roof. The height of a building with a flat or nearly flat roof, less than seven (7) degrees from the horizontal, shall be measured from the footing as stated above to the highest point of the roof. 2.13. Building line. A line delineating the minimum allowable distance between the street right-of-way and nearest extreme projection of a building (including all areas covered by any vertical projections to the ground or overhang, walls, roof, or any other part of the structure). 2.14. Building site. The ground area of a building or buildings together with all open spaces surrounded by said building or buildings. 2.15. Reserved. 2.16. Camper. A motor home, tent, trailer, or other self-contained vehicle designed for recreational purposes. 2.17. Care homes. Includes rest and nursing homes, convalescent homes and boarding homes for the aged; established to render nursing care for chronic or convalescent patients, but excludes facilities for care of active or violent patients such as feeble-minded or mental patients, epileptics, alcoholics, senile psychotics, or drug addicts. 2.18. Centerline, highway. The line running parallel with the highway right-of-way which is half way the distance between the extreme edges of the official right-of-way width as shown on map approved by the county tax assessor. 2.19. Certified survey. A survey, sketch, plat, map, or other exhibit is said to be certified when a written statement regarding its accuracy or conformity to specified standards is signed by the specified professional engineer, registered surveyor, architect, or other legally recognized person. 2.20. Child/adult care center. A facility operated by a person, agency, corporation, institution or any other group that provides care and supervision for children or adults and which is licensed by the State of Georgia. This use shall not be allowed in a residence. 2.21. Child/adult care home. A residence in which care and supervision are given in a family home for one (1) and not more than six (6) children or adults and which is licensed by the State of Georgia. This number shall not include children or adults who reside in the home. Only those residing in the home may be involved in the day-to-day operation of the child/adult care home. 2.22. Church. A legally approved structure and its accessory buildings used and approved on a permanent basis, primarily for the public worship of God. 2.23. Club, private. An organization or association of persons for some common purpose, such as, but not necessarily limited to, a fraternal, social, educational or recreational purpose; but not including clubs organized primarily for profit or to render a service, which is customarily carried on as a business. Such organizations and associations must be incorporated under the laws of Georgia as a nonprofit corporation and such corporations' major purpose shall not be for the purpose of serving alcoholic beverages to its members or others. This may not be located on, or operated by, or in connection with any commercial use. 2.24. Conditional use. Those uses allowed within a district, only after specific requirements are met. The local governing authority at its discretion may require additional restraints, restrictions, qualifications, or limiting factors upon a specific use so that it becomes acceptable. 2.25. Density. The number of units or buildings per acre, or the number of people per unit, building, acre or mile, the quantity of people, structures, or units within a specified area. 2.26. Depth of lot. The depth of a lot is the depth between its mean front street line and its mean rear line, measured along the median between the two (2) side lot lines. 2.27. Dwelling, condominium. A building or series of buildings on the same lot or portions thereof containing more than one (1) dwelling unit under separate ownership with joint ownership of common open spaces. 2.28. Dwelling, duplex. A residential building designed for, or used as, the separate homes or residences of two (2) separate and distinct families, but having the appearance of a single-family dwelling house. Each individual unit in the duplex shall comply with the definition for a one-family dwelling. 2.29. Dwelling, group. A building or portion of a building occupied or intended for occupancy by several unrelated persons or families, but in which separate cooking facilities are not provided for such resident persons or families. The term "group dwelling" includes, but is not limited to, the terms "rooming house," "apartment hotel," "fraternity house" or "sorority house," "Y.M.C.A." or "Y.W.C.A." A hotel, motel, or tourist home shall not be deemed to be a group dwelling as herein defined. 2.30. Dwelling, one-family. A private residential building used or intended to be used as a home or residence in which all living rooms are accessible to each other from within the building, and in which the use and management of all sleeping quarters, all appliances for sanitation, cooking, ventilating, heating, cooling, or lighting are designed for the use of one (1) family only on a minimum of a single lot. 2.31. Engineer. Any person having an acceptable degree from a recognized institution of higher learning who is capable of determining the correct manner in which to construct roads, streets, highways, water and sewerage systems, drainage system, structures or other technical-related areas. The person to be a municipal engineer must be recognized by the State of Georgia as one. 2.32. Estate. Any residential site comprising five (5) acres or more shall come within the meaning of the word "estate". 2.33. Family. One (1) person, or a group of two (2) or more persons living together, and interrelated by bond or consanguinity, marriage, or legal adoption occupying a dwelling unit designed as a single-family unit, with a single set of kitchen facilities. The persons thus constituting a family may also include gratuitous guests and domestic servants. 2.34. Floodprone areas. That land adjacent to a creek, stream, river, channel, canal or other body of water that is designated as a floodplain or floodprone area by a governmental agency. 2.35. Floor area. The sum of the gross floor area for each of the several stories under roof, measured from the interior limits or faces of a building or structure. 2.36. Floor area ratio. Floor area of building or buildings on any lot divided by the area of the lot. 2.37. Frontage. The distance or width of a parcel of land abutting a public right-of-way and as measured upon such right-of-way. 2.38. Garage, community. A structure or series of structures under one (1) roof, and under one (1) ownership, for the storage of vehicles by three (3) or more owners or occupants of property in the vicinity where said structure has no public shop or mechanical services in connection therewith. 2.39. Garage, private. A structure for the private use of the owner or occupant of a principal building, situated on the same lot as the principal building for the storage of motor vehicles with no facilities for mechanical service. 2.40. Garage, public. A structure for the storage, care, repair, or refinishing of motor vehicles, or a structure containing a public shop, or where automobile mechanical service is provided. 2.41. Gas station. A structure designated or used for the retail sale or supply of fuel, lubricants, air, water, and other operating commodities for motor vehicles and including the customary spacing and facilities for the installation of such commodities on, or in, such vehicles, but not including space or facilities for the storage, painting, repair, refinishing, body work, or other servicing of motor vehicles. 2.42. Governing authority. The mayor and council of a city or town or the board of commissioners of the county in which that city or town is located. 2.43. Highway. Any public thoroughfare of paving twenty-two (22) feet or wider including streets, which affords primary access to abutting property, and any thoroughfare of less width which is not classified as an alley (street). 2.44. Hospital. An institution providing health services, primarily for in-patients, and medical and surgical care of the sick or injured, including as an integral part of the institution such related facilities, central service facilities, and staff offices. 2.45. Hotel. A building occupied as the more or less temporary residence of individuals who are lodged, with or without meals, and in which there are ten (10) or more sleeping rooms with entrances through a common lobby or office. 2.46. House trailer. House trailer or mobile home means any vehicle or similar portable structure which was constructed with wheels so as to permit its being used as a duly licensable conveyance upon the public street, whether or not its wheels have been removed, and constructed to permit occupancy as a dwelling. 2.47. Junk. Old and dilapidated automobiles, trucks, tractors, and other such vehicles and parts thereof, wagons and other kinds of vehicles and parts thereof, scrap building material, scrap piping, bottles, glass, old iron, machinery, rags, paper, excelsior, hair, mattresses, beds or bedding, or any other kind of scrap or waste material which is stored, kept, handled, or displayed within the county limits. 2.48. Junkyard. Any land or building used for commercial storage and/or sale of paper, rags, scrap metals, other scrap or discarded materials, or for the dismantling, storage or salvaging of automobiles or other vehicles not in running condition, or of machinery or parts thereof, but not to be used as a dump. 2.49. Lot. Parcel of land shown on a recorded plat or on the official county zoning maps, or any piece of land described by a legally recorded deed. 2.50. Lot, corner. Any lot situated at the junction of and abutting on two (2) or more intersections or intersecting streets or public highways. If the angle or intersections of the direction lines of two (2) highways is more than one hundred thirty-five (135) degrees, the lot fronting on said intersection is not a corner lot. 2.51. Lot, interior. Any lot, which is not a corner lot, that has frontage only on one (1) street other than an alley. 2.52. Lot lines, front. In the case of a lot abutting upon only one (1) street, the front lot line is the line separating such lot from such street. In the case of a corner lot, that part of the lot having the narrowest frontage on any street shall be considered the front lot line. In the case of any other lot, one (1) such line shall be elected to be the front lot line for the purpose of this ordinance, provided it is so designated by the building plans which meet the approval of the zoning official. 2.53. Lot lines, rear. The rear lot line is that boundary which is opposite and most distant from the front lot line. In the case of a lot pointed at the rear, or any odd-shaped lot, the rear lot line shall be determined by the zoning official. 2.54. Lot lines, side. A side lot line is any lot boundary line not a front lot line or a rear lot line. A side lot line separating a lot from another lot, or lots, is an interior side lot line. 2.55. Lot, through. Any lot having frontage on two (2) parallel or approximately parallel streets or other thoroughfares. 2.56. Mapped streets. A mapped street is any approved street shown on an official map or the projection of any existing street through an unsubdivided parcel of land, whether the street is dedicated or in existence or not. 2.57. Marshland. All land subject to tidal action which is comprised of generally unstable soil materials commonly known as "hard or soft" marsh, which in its natural state is vegetated with marsh grass, reeds and similar growth and is usually characterized by poor loadbearing capacity. Marshland lies below an elevation of five and six-tenths (5.6) feet above mean sea level. 2.58. Manufactured house. A non-self-propelled vehicle or conveyance that is towable and supported on its own chassis, permanently equipped to travel upon the public highways, that is used, either temporarily or permanently, as a residence or living quarters. Such unit shall be considered a "manufactured house" whether or not the wheels have been removed and whether or not set on jacks, skirts, masonry blocks or other foundation. 2.58.1 Manufactured house. A structure or component thereof, designed primarily for residential occupancy which is wholly or substantially made, fabricated, formed, or assembled in manufacturing facilities and assembled on a building site, into a dwelling unit supported on a permanent foundation. "Manufactured houses" shall meet the rules of the state board of community affairs, Factory Built Dwelling Units (O.C.G.A. § 8-2-110 et seq.) 2.59. Motel, or motor hotel. A building or group of two (2) or more buildings designed to provide sleeping accommodations for transient or overnight guests with no common entrance or lobby. Each building shall contain a minimum of ten (10) residential units or rooms which generally have direct, private openings to a street, drive, or patio, etc. 2.60. Nonconforming lot. Any lot which is smaller than the minimum dimensions, area, or other regulations of the district in which the lot is located. 2.61. Nonconforming use. Use of any property or premises in any manner which does not comply with the regulations provided for the district in which the property or premises is situated, if such use was originally legally established at the effective date of this ordinance or any amendment thereof. 2.62. Parking space. That area required for the parking or storage of one (1) automobile, including necessary aisle or driveway space providing access thereto. 2.63. Planning commission. An appointed body of people by the local governing authority whose responsibilities include the guidance of growth and development within the municipality and interpreting of the various municipal regulatory ordinances. 2.64. Principal building. The building situated or to be placed nearest the front property line and the use of which conforms to the primary use permitted by the zone classification in which it is located. 2.65. Professional services. The conduct of business in any of the following or related categories: law; architecture; accounting; engineering; medicine; dentistry; optometric; osteopathy; chiropractics; optician; planning, or consulting of the nature of the aforestated categories and which do not include outside storage space for business vehicles or equipment. 2.66. Public body. Any government or governmental agency of the county, the State of Georgia, or the United States Government. 2.67. Public use. Use of any land, water, or buildings by a municipality, public body or board, commission or authority, county, state or the federal government, or any agency thereof for a public service or purpose. 2.68. Repairs. Restoration of portions of a building to its condition as before decay, wear or damage, but not including alteration of the shape or size of any portion. 2.69. Residential. The term "residential" or "residence" is applied herein to any lot, plot, parcel, tract, area, or piece of land and/or any building used exclusively for family dwelling purposes or intended to be used, including concomitant uses specified herein. 2.70. Restaurant. A building, room or rooms where food is prepared and served to a group of families, a club, or to the public and for consumption within the enclosed structure. 2.71. Right-of-way line. The outside boundaries of a highway right-of-way, whether such right-of-way be established by usage, dedication or by the official right-of-way. 2.72. Rooming house. (The terms rooming house, boarding house, tourist home, cooperative house and lodging house are used synonymously in this ordinance.) A building, other than a hotel or dormitory, where, for compensation and by prearrangement for definite periods, lodging or lodging and meals are provided for more than three (3) persons not related to the owners of the structure. 2.73. Rooming unit. Any room or group of rooms, forming a single habitable unit used for living and sleeping, but which does not contain cooking or eating facilities. 2.74. Setback. The minimum horizontal distance between the right-of-way line, rear or side lines of the lot and the front, rear or side lines of the building. When two (2) or more lots under one (1) ownership are used, the exterior property line so grouped shall be used in determining offsets. When a lot abuts on a street or road which has a right-of-way of less than sixty (60) feet, the minimum setback for front, rear, or side yard shall be increased by the number of feet required to provide the same number of feet from the center of the road or street, as if said road or street had a right-of-way of sixty (60) feet. 2.75. Site. An area designated as a separate and distinct parcel of land on a legally recorded subdivision plat or in a legally recorded deed. 2.76. Special exception. A use, specifically designated in this ordinance that would not be appropriate for a location generally or without restriction throughout a given zoning district but which, if controlled as to number, area, location, or relation to the neighborhood, would, in the opinion of the governing authority, promote the public health, safety, welfare, morals, order, comfort, convenience, appearance, prosperity or general welfare. 2.77. Story. That portion of a building included between the surface of any floor and the surface of the floor next above it; or if there be no floor above it, then the space between the floor and ceiling next above it. 2.78. Street. A dedicated and accepted public right-of-way for vehicular traffic which affords the principal means of access to abutting properties. 2.79. Structural alterations. Any change in the shape or size of any portion of a building or of the supporting members of a building or structure such as walls, columns, beams, arches, girders, floor joists, or roof joists. 2.80. Surveyor. A person who determines or delineates the form, extent, position, distance or shape of a tract of land by taking linear and angular measurements, and by applying the principles of geometry and trigonometry. 2.81. Structure. Anything constructed or erected, the use of which requires rigid location on the ground or attachment to something having a permanent location on the ground; provided, however, that utility poles, fences and walls (other than building walls) shall not be considered to be structures. 2.82. Subdivision. "Subdivision" means all divisions of a tract or parcel of land for residential purposes into two (2) or more lots, building sites, or other divisions for the purpose, whether immediate or future, of sale, legacy, or building development and includes all division of land involving a new street or a change in existing streets, and includes resubdivision and, where appropriate, to the process of subdividing or to the land or area subdivided; provided, however, that the following exceptions are included within this definition only for the purpose of requiring that the local planning commission be informed and have record of such subdivisions: (a) The combination or recombination of portions of previously platted lots where the total number of lots is not increased and the resultant lots are equal to the standards of the governing authority; (b) The division of land into six (6) or less parcels where no new street is involved and the resultant lots are equal to the standard of the municipality or county in which the division of land is being made. Plats of such exception shall be received as information by the planning commission which shall indicate such fact on the plats. 2.83. Trailer. A non-self-propelled vehicle or conveyance permanently equipped to travel upon the public highways that provides temporary use as a residence or living quarters or office; serves as a carrier of people, new or used goods, products or equipment; or is used as a selling, advertising or display device, whether or not the wheels have been removed and whether or not set on jacks, skirts, masonry blocks or other foundation. 2.84. Trash. Cuttings from vegetation, refuse, paper, bottles, and rags. 2.85. Use. The purpose for which land or a building is arranged, designed or intended, or for which either land or a building is or may be occupied or maintained. 2.86. Variance. A modification of the strict terms of this ordinance granted by the governing authority where such modification will not be contrary to the public interest; and where, owing to conditions peculiar to the property and not as the result of any action on the part of the property owner, a literal enforcement of the ordinance would result in unnecessary and undue hardship; and where such modification will not authorize a principal or accessory use of the property which is not permitted within the zoning district in which the property is located. 2.87. Vehicle. A conveyance for persons or materials. 2.88. Waterfront. Any site shall be considered as waterfront property provided any or all of its lot lines abut on or are contiguous to any body of water including creek, canal, river, or any other body of water, natural or artificial, including marshland, not including a swimming pool, whether said lot line is front, rear, or side. 2.89. Yard. An open space on the same lot with a building; said space lies between the building and nearest lot or street line. 2.90. Yard, front. That area of open space to the front of the platted lot, the area immediately adjacent to the street side of the lot. If streets bound on two (2) sides of the lot, the narrower portion fronting on a street shall be declared the front. (See Lot line, front.) 2.91. Yard, rear. That area of open space that is opposite the area delineated as the front. That area of greatest distance from the street. (See Lot line, rear.) 2.92. Yard, side. That area of open space that is immediately adjacent to the side lot lines. (See Lot line, side.) 2.93. Zoning ordinance. An officially adopted ordinance that regulates the manner, type, size and use to which a piece of property may be put. 2.94. Zoning Official. The executive director of the LCPC or his/her designee who shall inspect, determine compliance with, and render decisions concerning the compliance of structures and lots to the provisions of the Zoning Ordinance of Liberty County. (Mo. of 10-4-1977; Mo. of 6-9-1983; Mo. of 6-3-1986; Mo. of 6-30-1986; Ord. No. 2012-001, 3-15-2012) ARTICLE III. - GENERAL PROVISIONS
3.1. - Abandoned real property. 3.1.1. For any public street or alley which is hereafter officially vacated or abandoned, the regulations applicable to each parcel of abutting property shall apply to the centerline property which is abandoned. In the event abandoned property is not divided at the centerline for abutting properties, the zoning districts applicable shall apply to such ownership line as determined by virtue of such abandonment. 3.1.2. For any public property other than streets or alleys, the regulations applicable to the zoning classifications [of property] which abuts the abandoned property for the greatest number of lineal feet shall apply to the entire property. (Ord. No. 2012-001, 3-15-2012) 3.2. - Abandoned vehicles. Within all zoning districts except where specifically authorized, all vehicles which are inoperative and/or unlicensed shall not be abandoned in the public right-of-way or on private property in excess of thirty (30) days except within a completely enclosed garage, unless permission is granted upon application to the governing authority. (Mo. of 3-2-1982; Ord. No. 2012-001, 3-15-2012) 3.3. - Access control. In order to promote the safety of motorists and the pedestrian and to minimize traffic congestion and conflict by reducing the magnitude of and the number of points of contact, the following regulations shall apply: 3.3.1.
